content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
A decent game made great by its space battles and player modsPlenty of bang for your buck, with three campaigns, about a dozen turn-based conquest modes, and classic skirmish battles. However, if you're an experienced RTS fan, you might find the ground battles lacking. The unit controls are imprecise, the balance questionable, and the pop limit placed painfully low. That said, the space battles are magnificent. Each class of ship has its place, and the pop limit gives you far more breathing room. The game just shines here.And when vanilla bores you, check out some of the mods on moddb. I personally recommend the Revenge of Thrawn and Republic at War projects, both of which introduce a plethora of new units familiar to longtime Star Wars fans.

Posted: August 15, 2015
												I have only played this game for a little while after buying it, and I can say that it is good. Though, there are a couple downsides to it. Heres a list of Pros and Cons.Pros:-Game is fun, and plenty of strategies to experiment with.-Moding community is amazing.-Really is worth the money, with the free "Force of Corruption" Expantion.-3 factions to experiment and play with.-Real ships and vehicles from the movies (Including a couple that aren't).-Balancing is great, depends how you look on it though.-Maps that you can re-inact your favorite battles with.-You can build the Deathstar. 'Nuff said.Cons:-Gameplay is fairly limited.-Units are fairly limited.-Ground Battles aren't exactly bad, but they aren't great either.-Multiplayer servers shut down. (You can download third party programs to get multiplayer, though I havn't tried this yet).-No workshop. (Mod installing isn't as easy as it could be).So, these are my thoughts on this game. Buy it, it's definently worth it. I may edit this if I find anything in the future.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Star Wars: Empire at War is a real-time strategy game from Petroglyph and published by LucasArts, the best strategy game in Star Wars franchise. Gold Pack also include the expansion pack Star Wars: Empire at War - Forces of Corruption in one package.Star Wars: Empire at War takes place before and to the event of Episode IV, to the Battle of Yavin, while the expansion pack, Star Wars: Empire at War - Forces of Corruption follows the underworld faction Tyber Zann with the Zann Consortium.Star Wars: Empire at War gameplay is more like map conquest called galaxy conquest since this is the Star Wars galaxy, you start on a galactic map, establishes bases on planets like Coruscant, Tatooine or Naboo, build up armies and galactic fleet, then engage in space or ground battles on map in real epic battles. You get to command the Star Destroyer fleet with the Galactic Empire or squadrons of X-wing with the Rebel Alliance. This game can entertain you for many hours.While Star Wars: Empire at War has great gameplay, the graphics are somewhat, inadequate for me. Kind of like, ugly, but at least has some detail. The effect are not that great too, except for the Death Star. The performance are great nevertheless.The one of many greatest thing about this game is that there are many mods out there making this game even more interesting and fun, like Republic at War or Thrawn Revenge, try them.The downside of this game is with the expansion pack, Star Wars: Empire at War - Forces of Corruption, it still have many minor bugs that left unfixed. Although the bugs won't hinder your gameplay at all, but it is somewhat annoying.Very addicting game Star Wars: Empire at War is for strategy fans, you get to fight twice to capture a planet, a space battle and planetary battle. I recommend this.Rating 8/10

number of helpful: 103 of 108 people (95%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												Played this game maybe 80 hours on the old retail DVD and it has not aged a day in my eyes.  Game is a spiritual successor to Rebellion which in turn was a time sink i played in the 90's more than i care to admit. It was a awesome space strategy set in the star wars universe and it was deeply addictive and awesome in every way because it used the SW license to the max. And this game? Same but it goes even further and UI is now much better. More units, a proper space and land combat system, ships and races you wont be seeing in the movies much but will find in the SW lore and comics. Don't be afraid of the aging graphics. you won't be watching the ship details up close in space combat anyway. Detail level on planets is pretty good. nothing to be ashamed of much when compared to modern RTS games.  Game engine is solid and fun factor is very high.  Battles are simplified and will not satisfy more hardcore RTS audiences but as stated the fun factor is high and learning curve is low. It will not take long before you are laying out complex conquest plans on the galactic map.  DLC pack adds a new Zann Consortium faction to play. This faction is the only thing i don't quite like as it's so different from the base Empire and Rebellion factions. It is obvious it has been designed from the scratch to be as different as possible so how does that blend in well with the classic factions? Badly it seems. Certain units are OP when spammed and countering these OP units can be tricky which in my opinion breaks the beautifully simple paper-rock-scissors type of fighting that takes place between the two classic factions. 9/10 anyway. Grab it. Game is still worth it's price even today.

												I played the original disc version of this game before getting it again on steam.Despite its age I still think this is the best star wars RTS to date. content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												As of June or some other month in 2015, or maybe 2014, whenever GameSpy shut down, this game NO LONGER has multiplayer. In order to play with your buddies you will have to download and install a program such as Evolve or Tunngle, in order to play online over LAN. Star Wars Empire at War is a strategy game. Unlike some strategies, Empire at War is very basic. With little micro management, and a small unit cap. This makes it great for those new to the genre, who are looking to get into it. The gameplay is in real-time. Meaning it is actually fun, unlike turn-based titles. There are two types of battles: space, and land. In space battles you have a space station, which you can upgrade. Through this station, you build new units and buy upgrades for them, unlocking more units and upgrades as you upgrade the station. You must destroy the enemy's station to win. The land battles put you on a planet in the Star Wars universe. You have a base with multiple buildings, each one allowing you to buy different units/upgrades. As with the space station, you can upgrade your central command building to unlock more advanced technology. You must destroy the enemy's base to win. With both battle types, you can change the win conditions. So instead of just having to destroy their base, you have to wipe them out completely, etc. The Gold Pack comes with both the original Empire at War, and the Forces of Corruption expansion pack. Unfortunately Forces of Corruption has some balance issues, but the game is still extremely fun. The original game allows you to play as either the Empire or the Rebellion. It has it's own campaign, which is around 5 hours or so in length. But as with most strategy games, the campaign is more of a slow tutorial to prepare you for multiplayer. Forces of Corruption adds a new campaign, and also allows you to play as the Consortium. Which adds new units, upgrades, abilities, and requires you to change your strategy in certain ways. The multiplayer still has a very active, but very small, community. If you do plan to get the game, be sure to switch your location to the US in the options, otherwise you will see few, if any, matches. Empire at War is an excellent RTS, and definitely one to consider getting whether you are a veteran of the genre, or have never played one before.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												Star Wars: Empire at War puts you straight into the centre of galactic war in real time strategy fashion. Depicting the struggle of the Rebels, the Empire, and the Zann Consortium. The game is loosely set between the events of Episode III and Episode IV in Star Wars.Players have three campaigns to choose from. The Rebels campaign that takes them across the galaxy to stop the Empire’s advance and stop their new super weapon. The Empires campaign works closely with Darth Vader himself as he tries to crush the remaining Rebel forces, complete the Death Star construction and prevent the leaked plans getting in front of the Rebel leaders. lastly the Zann Consortium campaign where you seek to spread your corruption across the galaxy and earn vast riches along the way. All campaigns are very well written and while linear, they offer a few side missions to add some extra life to the campaign experience.In addition to those story driven campaigns, players can also take on the entire galaxy in the galactic conquest mode where players can play as the Rebels, the Empire or the Zann Consortium as they try to achieve particular objectives. There are a number of grand strategy elements present in these modes as you manage funds from the planets under your control and use those funds to improve your troops, research technology and more to get a leg up on the opposing forces. Also you can battle it out in shorter battles in the skirmish mode. Regardless of which you choose to get the Star Wars strategy experience from you’ll find a good mixture of vehicle, infantry and even spacecraft battles to enjoy.With plenty of Star Wars references and characters littered throughout the game, it’s a strategy experience that will definitely resonate with Star Wars fans more than anyone else. Star Wars fan or not though the strategy experience is worth playing with real time and grand strategy fans both catered for.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Star Wars Empire At War Gold is a super fun RTS game. It allows you to take control of either the Empire or the Rebellion (Also a faction called the Zann Consortium in the forces of corruption). They both play uniquely, and differ majorly on tech, the rebellion stealing tech from the empire, and the Empire making their own. You fight for control, sending fleets of starships into battle over planets, before launching seperate ground forces to completely conquer the planet. The gameplay is good, easy to control units and good user interface for anyone just coming into the genre. The Forces of corruption is a good addition to the game, allowing you to corrupt planets as well as take them over, giving you access to lots of nefarious things, even allowing you to enslave certain races, using them for cheap soldiers. The game is very good, and I give it a 8/10.

number of helpful: 40 of 42 people (95%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												SW: Empire at War + Forces of Corruption is basically the real time Total War version of Star Wars RTSs, boasting a feather-weight empire management overworld, where you will construct buildings that produce your Ships/troops on your planets, and send heroes/agents around to assassinate bothersome enemy heroes and play wack-a-mole with Zann Consortium corruption, before getting into space and ground combat to wrestle control of a planet from the AI's grubby mits.The Space Combat is where the game shines, even though the game has some annoying AI problems for their units, most of them can be ignored as they are minor and can be solved by just telling the ship to stop with the stop button on the command bar, or by just droping the SSD ontop of the enemy base before you bring in the rest of the fleet. And if/when you get mad, just start bringing the Death Star, an Interdictor and tie scouts with your "blob of death" and blow up their space station and have them commit suicide by attacking your wall of Star Destroyers and Ties head on.The ground combat while servicable is nothing spectacular and you can often spend minutes chasing that last remaining unit of rebel soldiers, and that is when you aren't getting constantly attacked by Jedi heroes and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t mobile fortress hero that all can infiltrate your planets with enough firepower to single-handedly beat off the Empire at Hoth. But very little can beat the coolness of commanding Veers and  a pack of AT-ATS, supported by airstrikes and planetary bombardment as they smash their way through an fortified rebel planet where even the natives wants to fight you.Now, the multiplayer is dead out of the box for the game, but if you can stand gameranger and can get it to work properly, then you might even get a couple of good MP games out of it too, just be prepared to get stomped by someone who has probably played the game since it came out back in the Bronze age.It is worth mentioning that the game still has a quite good, active and helpfull modding community that has produced everything from simple rebalance mods to humongus mods that are bigger than the base game.If you want purely a good Star Wars ground RTS go and buy Battlegrounds Saga, if you want a more comprehensive Empire management Star Wars game, go buy rebellion. If you however want the best(and possibly only) game where you control the Empire/Rebels on a galactic scale, while also controlling the space and ground battles yourself, then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												Hello! I have played this game alot and have enjoyed it severly! But that won't get you to buy it, will it cause everyone has their own tastes! Pros-Long gameplay, a single galactic conquest could take a couple days with breaks in between.Multiplayer, since the shutdown of gamespy it's been difficult to play multiplayer but with programs like gameranger you still can and it is VERY enjoyable.Battles, the battles are VERY fun but can sometimes get repetitive but thanks to the still active modding community and the DLC, this problem is solved.The tactics and strategy aspect, I, personally, am in LOVE with strategy and tactics and this game is full of it. A corvette cant beat a star destroyer head on but put that corvette in a ambush like position and it might stand a chance!Star Wars, must I really explain this part?The unpaid DLC, the DLC is very enjoyable with new units and a new side. Insteading of running around with stormtroopers why not run around with stormtroopers AND giant robots!ConsRepeat, this game can get very boring since the gameplay is limited to half a dozen land and space units on each side so it gets boring. But thanks to modding and the DLC it can be fixed.Modding on steam, its a bit annoying when installing mods on steam because you have to download the mod and find the steam folder and install it there them mess around the launch options. The community(including myself) has been BEGGING for a workshop integration for the game but there has been no luck...The campaigns,The campaigns are a bit frustrating and boring and the story is trippy.Unit size, the units are not realistic with its actual canon size. Boba Fett is half as large as an AT-ST, no matter how awesome you think he is.However the cons are solvable with modding and the game itself is VERY  fun! I definitly recomend this to star wars fans and RTS fans!

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												This is my favorite RTS of all time. Probably because I've never played C&C but anyways this is a very simple RTS but a very fun RTS too. First, there are the Space battles which are pretty fun and can be super epic. Then there's the land battles which are pretty slow and boring, there are some cool moments that can happen but you will most likely auto-resolve. There are 3 campaigns, Many Galactic Conquest modes, and Skirmish battles. Galactic Conquest is what I think is the best mode because you can conquer more planets and choose your approach. Campaign is a simple Star Wars story and teaches you how to play the game. Skirmish battles are land/space battles where you destroy the enemy base. Unfortunatly the game's multiplayer no longer works but you can play regular Empire at War (No Forces of Corruption because Steam counts it as DLC.) with Gameranger.What I do suggest if you get bored is that you download some mods. Some of my favorites are Republic at War, Thrawn's Revenge, and Super Star Wars: Rise of the Droid Empire. I give this game a 9/10 but I say get this game on the May 4th sale because thats the only time I've seen it on sale

content:
Posted: February 12
												Clunky glitchy, god awful. I Have 550 hours on this game. maybe a hundred of those were me being too tired to shut down the game properly at 4am and just letting it idle.No other rts has given me this experience. The defence on multiple fronts, the ever pressing need for better weapons, the heartbreak that fills me when one of my capital ships detonate, all hands lost. it is just amazing. ive played maybe a half a dozen mods, conquered the galaxy repeatedly using various factions. its all just so darn good.if you are an rts nut, this game is a must. if you are a casual player who wants something they can come back to and play this is a must. if you enjoy the modding scene, this is a must.Tips: don't auto resolve with ships in orbit, tech up before going on the offensive, build mines only on planets with a 50 or higher base income, and set a timer so you dont accidently play all night.MODS: most mods can be installed by creating a mods folder in ypur corruption folder, and then click and dragging the mod you downloaded into the mods folder. took a few tries but i got it down, some mods are weird, but not usually worth the extra effort. uninstall mod by clicking and dragging the file out of the folder. i just saved mod authors like 60 comments with that i swear to god. MODS, as witnessed by moiRepublic At War (RAW) while well polished visually, it is horribly unbalanced. republic easy campaign is 20 hours at the least. Cis Hard campaign was 8. i kid you not this mod is not finished balance wise.Clone wars mod is like the 2008 series. crashes occasionally, but better than RAWClone wars sub-mod has great Land combat just like the 2003 cartoon, but space battles are meh.Thrawns Revenge is pretty epic and very unique. exact opposite of RAW really. Very well balanced, but the visuals are not as good. granted unlike RAW this game isnt advertised as finished and gets a new beta in febuary of 2017Rise of the mandalorians is both interesting, stable, and Pretty to look at. also has the BEST turrets on ships unlike in vanilla and many other mods (again, RAW) Awakening of the rebellion seems like a dumpster, it has so much content from so many creators that it lacks stability. also has an annoying change to the way the camera works in space that ruins the top down atmosphere. overwrites your data folder for vanilla, thus requiring  a load of fiddling to uninstall.Ultimate Corruption feels like an expansion. it balances ship strength and fighter complement by class (light cruiser, cruiser, heavy cruiser, battlecruiser) allowing for you to pick and choose what you like. adds loads of new ships, makes stations awesome, and utterly destroys x wings. in closing, this game is ok vanilla, but fan made content shines it to a gleam.worth full price.10/10 would sink more hours into this than your average college course.

content:
Posted: January 3
												Luke, did I ever tell you these were your father's droids? We went on wild adventures together for over 3 years in the Clone Wars, and the little one even saved me from a swarm of buzz droids, yet I somehow don't recognize them anymore. They were good friends.Luke, did I ever tell you that while your father was training on Coruscant, C-3PO served your family (Uncle Owen, Aunt Beru, Grandma Shmi, Grandpa Cliegg) for nearly 10 years? Somehow, your uncle didn't recognize Threepio when he returned to family's service.Hey Luke, did I ever tell you that all Jedi used to dress like homeless moisture farmers the same as I do, despite that still dressing like a Jedi is no good way to hide from Empire? It was a good robe though.Come here, Luke, today we will be training with this practice droid while you wear this helmet to blindfold yourself. You would think this was an impromptu training procedure, but no, we did this to younglings all the time and even built them special mini helmets. Right now you are literally worse than a child, Luke, like the ones your father killed with that lightsaber you are holding. He was a good friend.You must go to Dagobah, Luke, and seek out Yoda, the Jedi Master who trained me — well, actually, he's A Jedi Master who trained me. Before I moved up to Liam Neeson's service, I was one of the 20 younglings who went to Yoda's class every tuesday and thursday back in youngling school inbetween Jedi chemistry class and lunchtime. Nothing remarkable or mystic to our relationship at all. He was just my teacher who handed out droids and youngling-sized helmets to the class. Also, all his deep seemingly spur of the moment lessons and teachings from a true master are all fairly common Jedi sayings that he just butchers with his ghetto way of talking. A good friend, he was.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												Star Wars Empire at War is a gem, perfect for those who are looking for a slow but entertaining real time strategy game that takes place in the Star Wars universe.Pros:-Challenging.-Includes a fun story mode and missions that are separate from the story.-Moddable.-Active Community.-Many locations from the movies and new places to invade.-Forces of Corruption is an expansion that adds a lot more content.-Famous heroes can be controlled, including Luke Skywalker, Boba Fett, and Han Solo.-Battle Camera can allow players view battles in a way seen in the movies.-The game can be replayed a ton due to Galactic Conquest and Skirmish.Cons:-The game can get repetitive without any modifications.-Without Workshop, modding can become difficult.-The artificial intelligence is not the best, sure you can be out-smarted by them in your first game but you will learn and there will be no way to lose.-Ground battles can be annoying, especially when you kill everything but one person is hiding somewhere.9.8/10Star Wars Empire at War is nearly perfect and the game is one of the games a true fan of Star Wars must play. I can't say anything about this game, it is just awesome.

content:
Posted: January 22
												Short Version: Get it at full price or on sale, worth it either way. Endlessly entertaining, tons of well-made mods.Star Wars Empire at War is one of my favorite games of all time and an incredibly fun RTS. I've been playing it for around 8 or 9 years now (most of that was a physical disc) and it has *never* become boring. It has very good balancing with a rock-paper-scissors strength/weakness system, and the strategic elements aren't too simplistic yet aren't as in-depth as, say, Sins of a Solar Empire. In the base game you play as the Empire and the Rebels, and in the Forces of Corruption expansion (which is what I'll be talking about during this review) you get the added Zann Consortium. They all have the gameplay styles and strengths as you'd expect from the movies. Empire is very straightforward in their attacks, can produce massive ships and use their superior technology to crush their opponents. The Rebels are more cautious and use methods like stealing technology from the Empire and relying on fighter support more than huge battleships. The Consortium is essentially the Rebel's stealing mechanic amplified, with systems like bribing and actively stealing money. All are fun to play as- it's satisfying to send a Super Star Destroyer into a weak Rebel base and dominate them, beat a seemingly-unstoppable Empire with a few squadrons of well-coordinated Y-Wing and X-Wing strikes, and to cripple powerful factions through espionage.The battles themselves are entertaining. Even if the same general scenario has played out before, it's still captivating to watch the ships on-screen battle and blow up system after system until one explodes and falls towards the nearby planet. Personally I think the space battles are MUCH better than ground battles. I usually have the game auto-resolve ground battles, but they are still enjoyable nonetheless. Oh, also, mods. The mods for this game are absolutely incredible, and if for whatever reason the base game doesn't satisfy you enough, perhaps the mods will. Want to add campaigns based off of the Thrawn Trilogy and play as factions like the New Republic, Pentastar Alignment, or the Empire of the Hand? Want to fight through the Vong War, and all the other awesome EU events that happened post-Return of the Jedi? (Or, sorry, our overlord Disney says those aren't canon anymore. But let's pretend they still are.) Get Thrawn's Revenge. Want to COMPLETELY convert the game from the Galactic Civil War to the Clone Wars? Get Republic at War. Want the same thing but you're not that good at strategy games and don't want to be brutalized by AI Opponents? (That would be me) Get The Clone Wars mod. In conclusion, just buy it. You won't regret it. And if you're that /one guy/ who DOES regret it and thinks that Disney's EU is better than the old EU, you can use that handy refund button.11/10 would destroy every planet with death star again

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												First, I'm gonna start with the pros:- No lack of content, you could play this for hour at a time.- Compatable with Windows 10.- The campaigns are very entertaining and interesting to follow.- You could always try a quick skirmish battle from the home screen if you're short on time.- The 'Forces of Corruption' pack has a really good EU story, it's also fun to play as a team other than the empire or rebellion in a GCW Star Wars game.- Very little lag.- Very few glitches.- You actually look at what your/the enemy's troops are good/weak against and use that information to win the battle instead of just aimlsessy making them all charge like hooligans.- ADAPT, ADAPT, ADAPT!- Snowspeeders are fun.- AT-ATs are even more fun.Now for the cons:- It's not fun  going against a snowspeeder or AT-AT when you don't have the opposite.- Not the best graphics, for those who care about it.- Units may sometimes be unresponsive, especially in space.- Special abilities don't always work.- It's sometimes hard to go from right click for move/attack to left click for the special ability.- Money is very rarely a challenge.- WHAT?! 4 SHOTS FOR A BLOOMIN' KILL FOR ONE PERSON, WHAT IS THIS?!- Some beginners may find easy mode feeling medium or hard (EDIT: The first few missions are normally quite hard, the rest rather easy).- Auto resolve is pretty harsh and unbalanced.- Most of the times that I tried out the Death Star it crashed (luckily it works for the campaign).Overall, it's a very good game with its cons being rather minor. The content has kept me up for days  yet I'm still going. It is very addictive and it's hard to just leave among all your other ditched games. It also is probably one of the very few games that is actually tactical, making you adapt to certain situations. 9/10.

number of helpful: 18 of 20 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Star Wars Empire at War combines a great combination of ground and space combat which not only looks great but also plays well.The game works around the idea of a galactic map with planets that you control. these create a general map that you have to conquer, each planet can change control to whoever conquers it and has two levels of defence that you can have.Ground defence allows you to have fight in traditional RTS ways where you have to eliminate the hostile forces to capture the planet  or stop an invasion force.Space combat allows you to bring large or small ships into combat using RTS gameplay, this creates great combat and gives you the oportunity to play as you want. there can also be a space station and defences that you can build / destroy making space combat vary in each fight.the game in general is good fun for anyone who likes RTS games with a unique take on the genre. i find that it is enjoyable and the game has its own fan made expansion which completely overhauls the game and changes the empire and rebels to republic and federation. This allows for an entirely new type of gameplay as the new units have far more weapon spots and units which makes your screen light up with turbo lasers.the expansion however can run a bit slugish if you go insane and spam battledroids as the game tanks and doesnt run too well.in general i would say if you like RTS conquest games then give this a shot, its pretty cheap now and the free expansion Republic at War allows for a near whole new game.

Of course he can do the same with your bigger ships.The "worst" thing: The textures don't scale well with bigger resoulutions, which is something you can overlook when you see the massive pieces of debris that fly phyiscal correct through space after a big ship goes down.Overall a solid 9/10

content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
												This game is the perfect game for any starwars fan! The modding community has allowed many adaptions to allow republic versus CIS and many, many more modes and maps. If anything I think the game is too short, I also think the AI needs to be harder for more intense game play. The models for the base game and even the models for mods are fantastic. The varying  units for each side are brilliant and really show the difference between factions. Even after playing the base game there are many tutorials to install new mods to allow new and exciting gameplay. When it comes to the forces of corruption aspect of the game I think it is an exelent new story for the galaxy. Being able to experience the way Zanns plans unvail and experience first hand the Wrath of the empire is incredible. Again all the game really would need is a harder AI for "Hard" or just a new difficulty level. In conclusion I would deffinetly recommend this game to star wars fans and even strategy game fans. C:And now to Forces of corruption, in general I quite enjoyed the campaign but it was kinda short in my opinion. On galactic conquest "Equal Footing" playing as the empire is quite hard, even on easy. I build the second death star and Darth Vaders flagship the executor. The Zann band of pirates controlled a small fleet and a handful of planets. I moved my main fleet to Kuat to build more star destroyers and support ships, Zann sent a defiler to corrupt Kuat and before I could remove the corruption they sabotaged the planet destroying all forces in space and on the ground putting the planet in nuetral. I lost the second death star and couldnot rebuild it. Now if you think about it zann consorptium is over powered, I did overcome the consorptium and held my ground but they can take out your ships and planets like theres nothing to it. Even with the over powerd consorptium I still enjoyed the challenge and still won.

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful31 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												We all know that Rebel terrorists are the greatest threat facing civilized society.  How can we, loyal children of the Empire, ever hope to rise above such subversive filth?  Thankfully, Star Wars: Empire at War exists, as a realistic simulator that readies Imperial cadets for the challenges provided by the drunken, racist Rodian-slayers and effeminate robots that make up the rank and file of the Rebels' immoral affront to civilized society.  Disregard revisionist history; Rebels shoot Greedo first, ask questions later.Empire at War deftly combines the challenges of space and land combat into a single RTS, with resource managment and allocation of troops around the galaxy being key to whether or not you can repel the vile, fish-headed "Admiral" Ackbar from cruelly dominating and subverting the otherwise good people of the Empire.  There is an option to play as the Rebels, but no one would ever do so, unless they were a social deviant in need of wholesome Imperial reeducation.

number of helpful: 12 of 13 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												This game is literally perfect, I have around 3000 hours of EaW and FoC as I have played them since release. I just recently bought the steam version so I could play online with other Steam players on Forces of Corruption via GameRanger. If you can get past the slight balance problems and bugs the game has you will enjoy it a lot. Pros: 1. Very cheap $$$ wise.2. Regular Empire at War is almost perfectly balanced.3. Both EaW and FoC have a very fun fast-paced Skirmish for Land and Space. 4. EaW and FoC's Galactic Conquest can give hours of entertainment. 5. Forces of Corruption has a very fun Campaign.6. Both EaW and FoC can run on low-end PC's with lower graphic settings while having the ability to look amazing on higher graphic settings. (Graphic enhancement mods exist as well)7. Both EaW and FoC have countless mods, custom maps and etc that extends the gameplay.8. Pretty easy game to mod and a good start if you want to learn how to mod games.9. Very simple map editor. Cons:1. Forces of Corruption isn't balanced. (Not even close)2. The Campaign's for Empire at War aren't the best and can get boring. (My Opinion)3. Multiplayer no longer works without 3rd party software such as GameRanger.4. Multiplayer can be very buggy and cause a lot of Synchronization Errors. (Via GameRanger)5. If you attempt to play Forces of Corruption online with another player with the Steam version then he must also have the Steam version. Steam players can't play with Retail Forces of Corruption players due to a version mismatch. (Does not effect regular Empire at War)6. The EaW AI is very dumb, the FoC AI is slightly better but still isn't that great. (AI Improvement mods do exist) If you are interested in playing the game online I truly suggest you download GameRanger at www.gameranger.com Official online servers were shut down due to GameSpy shutting down.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												As RTS games go, this title isn't going to redefine the genre in any way. But that doesn't stop it from being an enjoyable enough game, especially if you're a Star Wars nut. Personally i find the space battles to be the real highlight for me, they're just so much better than ground force battles. I also must admit to having NEVER played as the rebel alliance, i always play as the Empire... purely because their ships and vehicles look so much better! For this reason i'm not sure just how balanced the gameplay is in terms of unit strength or if the number of recruitable units varies to make up for the difference in strength... after all, sure an AT-AT is going to be pretty tough to beat, but i wouldn't fancy the rebels chances if the Empire could recruit as many AT-AT's as the rebels can recruit in soldiers!Those of you who want to play as the rebels will be at least partially pleased to hear that the AT-AT doesn't appear until VERY late in the campaign. Same applies to the vast Executioner class Star Destroyers, although those ships seem to be lacking in firepower and are little more than enormous target practice sites. The bad news for the rebels though is if the Empire manage to finish constructing the Death Star and retrieve the stolen plans, they've already as good as won. If you're playing as the Empire then consider this good news, especially as you then get to destroy 4 or 5 planets and revel in genuine global destruction.In terms of graphics and audio, this game is fine and has stood the test of time well. In terms of gameplay it's pretty simple, bringing in little in the way of new features to the RTS genre. So if you're a fan of Star Wars and like the established RTS style of game, you're going to really enjoy this. If you're looking for something new, this will be a very shallow game indeed.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												In only one word. Perfection. The pinnacle of Star wars games. This game, along with Battlefront II and KOTOR, forms a triumvirate based on success, technology, and most importantly,FUN. I won't make this beginning too long, beacuse, if you are seeing this, you have probably played prefection already. But for those who haven't played (what are you waiting for?)I'll elaborate on some aspects of the game.NOTE:In this anylisis I'm writing about the gold pack itself. Apart from a few exceptions,I won't make any distinction between the original EaW and FoC-Graphics7/10Well, yes, I have talked of perfection and all of that stuff before, but, the graphics aren't perfect. The original game graphics are poor and cheap.The battles are truly spectacular,specially the space battles.Land battles aren't that wonderful, but they are playable and fun.-Duration10/10I won't talk much about this aspect. The "Galactic Conquest" mode can last for days, and you can repeat it  again the next day and have brand new posibilities! This game is REALLY long.-FUN FACTORWe finally arrived at this aspect. The previous two were just a warm up.Now is whe the real review begins.It's completely awesome.Period.Okay.You're still reading this.Then you are interested in the game.It's clear now.The game features the Galactic Empire, The Rebellion, and, in FoC, The Zann Consortium. The main Campaign drives you through the perils of each of the factions, though the Consortium is only available in FoC.Then there is the "Galactic Conquest" in which you control one of the factions to ultimate galactic domination, crushing, liberating or corrupting.And there is also a skirmish mode, but you guys must already know what entails.In fact, the feeling of crushing Echo Base(Hoth) with your AT-At's is wonderful. There isnm't any feeling like it.Well, this is all, finally, I can only say that.... 12/10.PERFECTION.Once more,yes.[/i]Overall game mark: 9/10I told you just a bit earlier that there isn't a feeling like crushing echo base,but, there is one.Writing this review sitting back and relaxing with my cup of tea, listening one of my favourite Dire Staits song.If you have read this....Thanks.It's been a pleasure.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												Empire at War is not your typical strategy game and definatley not your typical 4X sins of a solar empire/ star ruler etc brand of space strategy either. And despite that Empire at war really isnt anything special even back when it cam out  over a decade ago EAW Was not that innovative or edgy, or even orgional..this game uses a tried and true method that the total war series took up and perfected upon, Like total war it Empire at war sports a simple enough turn-based campaign map along with an equally simple easy to use Real-time battle map.Now, even with all that Empire at war is unique for that fact that you can not really find anything equivalent that does not require hours upon hours upon hours to complete Or is so superficaly put together or badly designed that enjoyment tends to be losst after a meere few hours of play. Empire at war is a rather thin game without all that much depth..or width but whats contained within the admitedly narrow scope of this game makes up  for it all tenfold. Personally i have rarely seen such a well put together bug free game with amazingly designed graphics that can still hold relevance today ((although that point is probably more opinion based, still point dersrves to be made)) along with the fact that this games devs put the time and effort into going over every single inch of this game making sure that pretty much everything is polished and finished. this is probably one of the most well made games you could run across..its just old. To sum this up simply put, imagine total war rome in space minus the minor social management and diplomatic features boil it down to war and you have Empire at war.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Star Wars Empire at War is a gem, perfect for those who are looking for a slow but entertaining real time strategy game that takes place in the Star Wars universe.Pros:-Challenging.-Includes a fun story mode and missions that are separate from the story.-Moddable.-Active Community.-Many locations from the movies and new places to invade.-Forces of Corruption is an expansion that adds a lot more content.-Famous heroes can be controlled, including Luke Skywalker, Boba Fett, and Han Solo.-Battle Camera can allow players view battles in a way seen in the movies.-The game can be replayed a ton due to Galactic Conquest and Skirmish.Cons:-The game can get repetitive without any modifications.-Without Workshop, modding can become difficult.-The artificial intelligence is not the best, sure you can be out-smarted by them in your first game but you will learn and there will be no way to lose.-Ground battles can be annoying, especially when you kill everything but one person is hiding somewhere.9.8/10Star Wars Empire at War is nearly perfect and the game is one of the games a true fan of Star Wars must play. I can't say anything about this game, it is just awesome.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Let me start by saying I do believe this is worth buying but I caution you if you are a fan of RTS games that this may not be what you are used to. The modding community has also done wonders with this game and for the Republic at War mod alone is worth buying the game.The game is split into 2 distinct parts. The galaxy overview where you build bases, move your troops and play in a Risk like format. The second part is the the RTS side of the game where you control your troops directly. This is further split into space combat and ground combat. I'm going to give each a review and then add the sum for my total review.First with the ground combat it always involves protecting or destroying the buildings. The defending side get's units through deployed troops already built and gets further free troops from buildings designed to construct units. The offensive side I find often is at a disadvantage and it becomes of game of invading with totally overwhelming numbers or playing more tactically with stealth based units. This generally ends up being long winded and downright boring battles in the later parts of the game where the combat is meant to be more fast and furious to keep a game going. For the ground combat I'd give it a 2/5.Second the space combat. This is where the game really shines and you can recreate some of the great moments from the movies. The Rebels and the Empire both play very differently and it keeps the fights fresh each time. The Imperials go for that ovewhelming numbers and get free Tie Fighters and bombers from the capitol ships. The Rebels why they need to buy Fighters and Bombers are generally more well rounded to deal with threats. Capitol ships on both sides play fairly the same with your standard Rebel Crusiers and Star Destroyers but what makes space combat so unique is that larger ships and space stations have hardpoints to target. To many Tie fighters take out the hangar. Mon Calamari Cruiser flanking around you take out its engines and leave it stranded. This adds a whole new dimension to and RTS that I've never played before and makes it a truly tactical experience. Space combat gets a 5/5.Finally the Galaxy Overview portion. It's fairly straightforward and just involves moving units, building bases on planets, sabatoging enemy bases and upgrading the tech tree. For players who don't want to play the battles can actually play and entire match from this screen and let the computer simulate the battles for you. It's different, it's cool, it's noting totally special but does offer a new take at strategy games. The Galaxy overview gets a 4/5.Don't expect much difficulty from the computer. The AI is somewhat dissapointing but fear not. One of the best parts of this game is what the modders have created for it. The Republic at War mod can take the place of the expansion and allows you to play out the Republic vs. Seperatist conflict. The AI in that is tough. I'm at the point where all I play is Republic at War and it offers the challenge that I was looking for from an AI in an RTS. AI gets a 4/5.So when you add it up the game is a 15/20. That takes into accounts both the vanilla game and the modded game. The modded version is much better and totally free so it's absolutely worth getting. Vanilla version is more for people who want to learn the game or are big Star Wars fans. In all it's not super difficult and definately different from most RTS games on the market. I definately recommend this game!

												Empire at War is an RTS dream come true for Star Wars fans.The mix of land battles, space battles, and the macro scale of controlling the galaxy makes this game a unique experience.You don't have to be a Star Wars fan to appreciate the experience, but fans will find this game better than non-fans simply due to the IP.Today, there are many board games and table top games devoted to representing Star Wars. content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												This game is a great RTS, which is good in its own right, but it's also set in the Star Wars universe, thus making it awesome!Honestly, I have yet to really play Empire at War as I have become enthralled by one of the game's many mods, Republic at War.This mod is based on the Clone Wars rather than the Imperial Era and is well worth the download.Some reasons this game is so good:Easy for a complete noob (i.e. me) to start playing.Has solid multiplayer (with the help of Evolve or other similar software).Is the only game that allows full immersion in Star Wars battles on such a grand scale.As of this moment, I have barely touched on the Galactic Conquest gamemode. But if you play smart, you can amass a colossal fleet of Star Destroyers and cripple everyone, which is amazing to watch.Some interesting things that have happened so far:My friend had a full population of B1 Battle Droids, I had an orbital strike and annihilated said Droids.In a 2v2 game: Other team attack all our mining facilities, they lose to teammates Acclamators.He attacks their base, a solid stalemate. I then send in the 6 Venators I've been stockpiling. Win.I start my first Galactic Conquest game. 5 minutes later. Alderaan is being attacked. I have 2 Venators and a couple of other ships defending it. Droids have 13 of their biggest cruisers. I lose.In short AI > friends.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Having logged countless hours in the retail version back when retail was up-to-date, I was eager to play it again and replay an awesome RTS in the SW universe.  Now before the actual review, I would like to warn windows 8 users: MAKE SURE THAT YOU DO NOT BUY THE RETAIL VERSION!!! You will find this game super cheap on Amazon, E-Bay, etc, but they will not run correctly on win8 systems. There is an official patch to fix this, but it doesn't always fix the whole problem. However, you will not need to patch and/or modify the game on steam to work :) Now for the review:Yes EaW is old, but it can compete with most current RTS games pretty well. EaW brings cool ideas to the table like space battles, hero units, and a conquest mode in which you have to conquer the galaxy!!! While EaW wasn't the first to do some of those things, they sure did them right. Ok now time for the generic Pros and Cons section:Pros:Doesn't feel repetitiveHas a large map varietyExplores a part of the SW timeline from an interesting new perspectiveIt's in the SW universe!!!Space BattlesBalancing is ok (Aside from the Rebels and their suprise armadas out of nowhere!)Zann Consortium adds a fun new play styleConsKinda pricy for an old gameGraphics (Expected from an old game)Battles should be bigger (There's probably a mod for that)MP is dead :( (There are programs for running MP on Gamespy dependent games though, look up Evolve or Gameranger)Rebels are really OP and can do massive suprise invasionsConclusion:If you like Star Wars, RTS games, or both, then buy this game. If you are looking for stunning graphics and scripted events every minute, then this game is not for you. If you found this review to be good, please mark it as helpful, but if not, then please mark it as not helpful so I can re-write it :)

Posted: August 5, 2014
												I would rate this game a steady 9/10, as it has mostly pros, and a few consPros:You could play for hours on end without the game getting boring or repetitive.There is a good modding community, crap tons of mods, and the mods are easy to installThe game is correct, as it follows all the books, movies, and comics (extended universe)There is an exellent community, and online is fun (if i could figure out my gamespy password), in FoC, (Forces of Corruption) you get to play as a pirate faction, and FoC has more mods than the normal gameCons:the guy who made the AI was probably high (just a fair warning).A few minor bugs.(for thoughs who care) the original graphics are pretty OK (not going to lie, they're not the best), but you can get mods that enhance the graphics.All said, the game is solid, loads of fun, easy to understand, and better than 80-90% of all other strategy games i've played, and last IF YOU THINK YOU WANT THIS GAME AND IT'S ON SALE; GET IT!!!I hope this review helps, and encourages any one looking to buy this game to do it.

												You are part of the Rebel Alliance, and a traitor! Take her away!Empire at War and Forces of Corruption is a great RTS and so much fun! The age of the game barely shows - it's still a beautiful Star Wars game and its especially fun as one. I love how accurate the units are - there are alot of different TIE Fighters and theyre represented perfectly in game. The same for the Rebel Alliance and the Zann Consortium. The storyline is fun, galactic conquest is even better and for you quick fixes, there is skirmish mode. You can download and play custom game maps as well! For the price, I highly suggest this game to any RTS fan and definitely to any Star Wars fans! May the Force be with you.

Posted: October 28, 2014
												I recommend this game becuase it's a star wars strategy game and if you like star wars and strategy games this is the game for you. I personally play this game becuase of the galatic conquest were you star off on a couple of planets, then you start to build your army up and fleet, then attack the enemy planet and capture and defend it you can also build the DEATH STAR as the Empire. The skirmish mode is great aswell, there are three factions you can choose from The Empire, Rebel Alliance and the Zann Consortium, They all have a great verity of troops in space or on the ground. The other  thing I like about this game is the AT-AT the Empire have and they can drop troops which is amazing, so for a example get 2 AT-ATs go to a capture point drop some troops off let them capture it then get your troops and the AT-ATs to storm the enemy base. The one thing I dislike is the ground battles when you capture a point and call some troops in and a ship comes down which is awesome but they your troops are very open for attack and some times which happends to me alot is if you play against hard AI, If there the Empire and they have a AT-AT and it's at your capture zone you call some tanks to deal with it, Then the ship comes down and the AT-AT destroys them which is a waist of cash. But apart from the "spawn killing" it's a wonderfull game and I highly recommend it to anybody

												If you wish to get into strategy games then I would recomend starting here, it is a RTS strategy not like the Total War series which is a turn based strategy with many things such as polotics, but Star Wars Empire At War dosen't have any of that stuff. content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												This is going to be a warning more than a review. I played many, many hours of this game as a kid and I bought it on steam because the Forces of Corruption expansion wouldn't install properly on my computer. This game installs and plays but let me warn you, SAVE OFTEN. Do not count on the autosave. I got some PTSD from the steam version after I played some hours in the campaigns. The game has some serious game breaking bugs. You may not get them, you will be lucky to get them 1 out of every 5 times you play the campaign. But when you do, you will want to tear your hair out. The one I got in the steam version (similar stuff happened on the disc version) was when I moved a character to do a mission within the time a scripted sequence was occuring in dialogue (IIRC) and he bugged out inside the planet. I needed him for the next mission but he was stuck in the planet. What's supposed to happen is you get your character back after a small period of time but that didn't happen. The autosave happened right after that so my save file is unplayable. SAVE YOUR GAME.Edit: I decided to do a retrospective video on the game to provide more information: 


YouTube™ Video: Buried Gems: Star Wars: Empire At War

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												This game really inspires my inner star wars fanboy. Everytime I boot Empire At War up, I quiver down to the deepest fiber of my being. I am enamored with concept of commanding an armada of space nazis in a universe where the laws of physics are cartoonish and the extent of technological doctorine is more shortsighted than trying to romance your unforgiving boss's daughter at the company christmas party. Inspite of the very massive flaws in the Star Wars univers, I still love playing as a glactic hegemony whose best option for soldiers are ordinary humans in hardshell space diapers. I love swooping in and using projectile weapons that have subsonic muzzle velocities that can be hit like a baseball by a glowing laser stick. Often times I will fantacize about being a sith lord and I wonder to myself why anyone would subject themselves to the self righteous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ry of the Jedi Order. Its deep thoughts like these that get me through days of choking down Mountain Dew soaked Cheetos and constant reposturing to cope with chronic back pain. Most discomfort in my life can be offset with a successfull planetary invasion in this game. The tactical and strategic interphases are incredibly intelectually stimulating and I feel great accomplishment with every victory. On a good day of playing this game I can feel my self esteem increase and sometimes I even muster up the courage to say "Hi" to cute girls I see at the local grocery store when I go to get more Mountain Dew and Doritos. Overall this game is quickly becoming a lifestyle for me. I came. I saw. I conquered. This is my new motto. Becuase of all the euphoria I experience from this game, I will give it a solid five out of five Fedoras. Now only if someone could make an Evangalion mod for this game.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												There are three Star Wars games that should really set the bar for any that follow them: Star Wars: Jedi Knight III: Jedi Academy, Star Wars: Battlefront II, and the one you are looking at right now, Star Wars: Empire at War.Essentially a Total War game in the Star Wars universe, albeit with a realtime campaign map as opposed to turn-based, this game offers a deeply enjoyable RTS and Grand Strategy experience, all set in the wonderful world of Star Wars. Play the Empire and crush the rebellion with your lumbering fleets of Star Destroyers and the legendary planet-destroying planetoid, the Death Star. Alternatively, shatter the tyranny of the Empire as a fledgeling Rebel Alliance, utilizing fast and agile ships to run circles around your foe.Ultimately, of the three gameplay modes, Space Battles are where the game design shines the most, followed closely by the campaign map, both of which overshadow, by a large degree, the lackluster ground battles. But this is not an issue. The Space Battles and Campaign map are so engrossing that you will likely get more fun and replayability out of those two modes alone, than a version of this game where more time were diverted to making better ground battles.Ultimately, I highly recommend this classic gem of a game to Star Wars and strategy gaming fans alike!P.S. I have probably over 200 hours in this game on the CD version, which I had since barely a month after its release!

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												This game is the best Star Wars game that has ever been made in the history of mankind. Better than Battlefront. Better Jedi knight II. Even better than KOTOR. It's a thoughtfully made strategy game, that wisely keeps you focused on the military side of things instead of making you deal with agricultural or political problems. Land combat, granted, is nothing special. You've experienced this kind of thing before if you've played a Total War game. Space combat is where the game really shines. It feels like nothing else, and does a great job of making you feel like a powerful fleet commander. If you secretly dream about being a the commander of a powerful fleet putting the planet below you under siege, this is the game to you.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Although a very very old game, it provides an excellent blend of Galactic management, ground tactical battles, and space tactical battles.The best parts:Interactive galactic map that, while it appears overwhleming, it actually extremely simple. Planets have space stations, ground structures, and special effects based on the specific, such as planetary weather or tactical advantages such as production discounts for specific units.Space battle mechanics. Frigates, Cruisers, Capital ships and Space Stations have "Hardpoints" that have different functions, like torpedo launchers, turbolaser cannons, shield generators, or engines. The hardpoints are individually selectable as targets and can be destroyed in any order. As hardpoints are destroyed, the ship loses functions, for example destroying turbolaser cannons will silence them, destroying shield generators permanantly disables shields, and destroying engines reduce speed and manuverability.The hardpoints also have limited firing zones. What his means, is that turrets can only engage targets in their cone of fire, so it's possible for skilled tacticians to ambush larger ships and hit them in their "Blind spots" to gain a tactical advantage.Each factions has it's own unique line-ups of ground forces, starships, and heros. Each one is unique, and nearly all units have special abilities to exploit. All units also have carefully designed strengths and weaknesses, and using each one correctly is the key to success.  No point-and-click tank and plane wars where the bigger army wins. A small force of well-played units will trump a large force of point-and-click steamroller armies.Of course, the game is a bit outdated. The graphics aren't up to date, and the game sacrifices intense, specific battles. It makes up by combining all 3 levels of command in a simpler way that caters to smart, creative tacticians rather than "Point-and-click steamrollers" who are used to just ordering a hundred tanks and craming them down the enemy's throat.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Great game if your looking for awesome space battles!Pros: - SPACE BATTELRUUUU~- A dated game, yet explosions and ships don't imeadiately disapear, I love how the hunks of destroyed ships fall slowly into the abyss away from the field.- Awesome spawning in system, team battles are amazing.- Mostly balanced races for fun all around actual games!- Mauler Mithel- I mean Darth Vader in a tie counters everything but Darth Vader in a Tie (dat XWING tmg reference)Cons:- LAND BATTLES D: so much potential... so much tank spam- AT-ATs provide free supply of squads, actually very game breaking when you have enough- Assault speeds counter everything. Harpoons in the future are the key to controling the universe apparently.- The NINE supply... MFW- Confusing and very annoying/frustrating when trying to build your units, why not be like the space battle and have everything built/unlocked at one key location? WHY BREAK YOUR OWN GAME!?- The ultimates are ultimately useless until you knock out the shield generators- and even then, they really don't do that much damage, and are too slow that you literally need the force to make them connect with anything viablly tactical.Final Review/Opinion:Great game overall, if the supply lock wasn't so low for un-modded battles, this would be an even better game, but even with the supply locked to a default the battles are intense, and every choice or reinforcement you call in is a  carefully decided choice. Should you go for the giant capital ships, slow but powerful? Or should you field a specialized fleet of fast movers capable of dodging the fire and taking out his big supply units? Micro versus Macro, fleet ships engage with decent AI, fighter squads also engage in decent AI at a ship to ship level of combat. The ground battles are giant blobs however, whoever has the better blob wins. If you see this game on sale, buy it! a must have for every sci-fi nerd or anyone with two eyes!

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												This will be what could be described as...a "mixed" review. I recommend this game for any star wars fan out there that wants an RTS fix. I can't recommend this game to rts fans. It is a very straight forward and shallow game that basically amounts to having more units than the other side. There are actual strategic elements that are brought in through community mods and add-ons, but the vanilla game is sorely lacking in this area. There is also a steep difficulty curve between the easy and medium modes. Note, I never gave the multiplayer a shot. +community support for mods and add ons.+Star Wars name +mixed space and ground combat keeps things interesting+fun to live the role of stratego for epic space battles-lack of depth to rts elements-once all units unlock, the end result becomes foregone-steep difficulty curve between easy and medium. Easy mode the computer is ridiculously easy. In medium mode, the computer's aggression is turned to 10 and development of a military force is much more time consuming. It becomes a matter of consolidation of resources and base defense.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												STAR WARS™ Empire at War - Gold Pack is an enjoyable RTS based in the Star Wars universe. Including the expansion, there are three factions. These factions are called the Empire, the Rebels (or Rebellion), and lastly the Zann Consortium. Each of these three factions has a nice variety of ships and land units to choose from for upcoming battles. Each faction also has their own type of research which gives the game more variety. The Rebellion has to send one of their hero units to an enemy faction to steal technology. Usually this tech that the Rebellion steals is a unit or building. The Empire must have a research base on the planet that they want to research tech levels which gives them a new tier of buildings and units. The Zann consortium cannot steal tech, but they can send hero units to planets with a black market to get unit upgrades. Now on to the maps: By default there aren't many maps to choose from unless you mod it. Each map has a set number of planets that your faction can control. You can build up to 8 buildings on any planet you control, although you won't be getting 8 slots on most planets. You may also build a space station above that planet, which can be upgraded up to 5, but depends on the planet. Land combat is quite dull in many peoples' opinions but space combat is quite good. There are also many mods to choose from that give the game much more replayability which I would suggest getting after a couple playthroughs. I've personally played Republic at War and I enjoyed it, a nice change from the base game. I did experience a few crashes and a bug, but that's expected from a mod. This game does feature a campaign for all three factions, which I think you should play through as well because they aren't bad. Lastly, I believe I'm right in saying the Zann Consortium is overpowered if you play them. You can fix this by modding or not playing them. If you don't believe me, you probably will when you play them. Just spam out the hovertanks.I'd give this game a 9/10 because it's pretty amazing. Some people might think it gets repetitive, but not me.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												A fantastic, well-developed, excellently made strategy game that is incredibly fun to play, and simultaneously challenging to a very customiseable degree.The rebellion are annoying to fight against, with strong abilities to evade space fights and strike right at the ground, having the most number of heroes and the strongest collection of force users. Their space units aren't too shoddy eitherThe Zann consortium are a nice, interesting faction, able to corrupt planets to make invasions easier. they have the most credits of anyone, and are incredibly survivable compared to the other two factions, able to stick around through deviousness and stealth, like the rebels. They lack any particular strengths in terms of space or land, but their Droidekas and Canterous Tanks make excellent ground forces, and their Keildabe-class battlecruisers aren't too shoddy.The Empire is glorious. Pilot the SUPER STAR DESTROYER Executor in climactic (and very one-sided) battles across the galaxy, exploding space stations and planets with the Death Star and being incredibly intimidating and awe-inspiring. The Empire, despite less population space in space, is clearly the winner in any machup, and on ground the formidable arsenal of AT-AT's, Stormtroopers, AT-AA, Sith, and repulsor tanks makes them nigh impossible to remove without heavy losses or superior tactics.Empire at war is for anyone who has ever wanted to feel the sheer power of commanding thousands of units into space battle against thousands of other units. For the Empire!

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												Fun Star Wars game. Bad RTS game.You can play as either the Empire or Rebels. Both play very differently and require full attention in all the battles. The difficulties are minute in difference and the AI is garbage. The good thing from this game is Galactic Conquest mode, which feels like you are actually taking over/freeing from the enemy for complete domination.The Gold pack includes Empire at War and the expansion 'Forces of Corruption'. Both are the same technically with the add on of a few new models/units and a new faction which brings a new experience to the game that doesn't focus on combat. The new faction lets you play as a pirate faction call the Zann Consortium. your main focus is to corrupt planets and do "side battles" which let you sort of unlock another way to corrupt a planet. Corrupting a planet doesn't give you full control but you can sabotage buildings, unlock tech, or bribe past planets.If you like having outrageous Star Wars battles then I highly recommend getting this game. If you are looking for a well balanced RTS game, don't get it.If you are feeling like you've done everything in the game, check out these fantastic mods.Republic At War: http://www.moddb.com/mods/republic-at-warImperial Civil War: http://www.moddb.com/mods/thrawns-revengeEdit: Take note that most mods that increase the population count will crash the game towards engame in Galactic Conquest.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												dont know why im able to review this game because I dont actually own it. however i have played it a fair bit. its really good and kinda complicated, and scratches a personal itch with the films. you see it urks me that farmhands that "reckon they can shoot good" with no training can beat fully armored, military trained, disciplined and equiped with the best armor and blasters stormtroopers. (that and sticks and stones can pierce the armor and kill them instantly........yeah....no) so now with this you can squash the scum! i literally never played the rebel filth. you can conquer the galaxy using all the iconic vehicles and troops from the films. i cant describe the rebels much as i never played them (empire only). but what i can say is that you can have famous imperial (and a certain sith) as units to use (they are really powerful! badass too) and some of the agents you can use are also iconic (such as being able to use a certain green bounty hunter to root out spies and smugglers). I assume that the rebels do a similar thing, having iconic rebel characters and functioning in a similar way (but also die pretty good, their buildings are also pretty when they explode). you can build buildings that supply troops and money and research for tech (only the finest for the glorious imperial army). it is kind of hard though, and as someone who hasn't got a mind for RTS's (yet loves them with a passion, my favorite genre of games). i found that the only way i could win sometimes was to simply bring bigger numbers of troops (overkill planets basically). theres also an overlaying story. now whats REALLY golden here, is that you can play as a crime syndicate faction. with loads of new shady activities you can do (its really fun) and some awesome story missions about your characters rise to a seat higher up then jabba the hut! personally I mainly undermined the rebels in this factions playthrough (but uh also did some business with them, i am a shady faction afterall). if you love star wars and like RTS's. this games for you, as steal at this price (and is on sale in the christmas sale at the time of this review)

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												one of if not the best strategy game EVER!although i should technicaly say ''games'' as this is the combination of both the original and the expansion.  this game seemlessly combines a civ builder and a strategy game together to fully emerse the player in the star wars universe WITHOUT screaming ''star wars om nom nom.  only star wars fans all others excluded''  (infact many star wars fans of other star wars games feel alienated by this game)  however for the fans they will find many of thier favorite ships aswell as some interesting new ones and allot of backstory and info they might not have nowne otherwise.  as for the game?  its a fun ALL real time strategy/civ builder.  everything is in real time.  everything is linked together.  from strategy map> space map> ground battles> taking over planets for the strategy map in a fast paced but fun way.  of course if you simply want to see GIANT ships firing HUNDREDS of lasers at each other then you can simply jump into the battles with space and ground skirmishs.  and the expansion? no it isnt some small add on or a tiny little pack but a full new campaigne and my favorite faction.  enter the consortium, a chaotic space mafia bent on ruling the universe!(ses economy) consortion adds not just new ships but also a unique and interesting and totaly new tech level upgrade sytem... stealing.  you can even steal ship disigns from the other factions and make them your own (though technicaly... uh oh that would be a spoiler)  the multiplayer is fun though it is an old game and therefor its probably best to find a friend that plays it.  additionaly the factions arent balenced very well but the expansion does add some balancing by making the rebel faction dominate the consortiom but not to the level that the empire dominates or the consortiums pure awsomness.  a multiplayer co-op campaigne would also have been cool but alas we can only dream.  there is however, a multiplayer co-op skirmish that is an interesting take on an age old idea (by that i mean starcraft :P)

It's not a pretty looking game, and the sense of scale is a bit off sometimes, if not completely, but it is still a very good game and if you like RTS games, but don't want to think very much, then this is perfect for you. Plus, you can use the Death Star to blow up planets. That right there should be enough to sell this to you.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												This is a great game for strategy fans, the fact it's Star Wars is just gravy. It's very similar in ways to Space 4X games, like Endless Space. Of course it's not that deep, but Empire at War is a nice mix of RTS and 4X. You Start out on the Galactic Map in most cases, in which there are numerous planets, each producing a certain amount of Credits, this games only resource/currency. You use Credits to purchase buildings on the planets you control, and Space Station upgrades once you purchase a Space Station in Orbit around the planet. You then build/recruit land units like tanks and infantry, or build spaceships ranging from small Fighter Ships, to large Capital Ships. You can create fleets containing Ships meant for battle, or just transport ships to carry troops. You can keep troops on your Battle ships, but I find it better to send the fighting ships first, THEN send the transports to take control of the ground.One thing I like is that in ground battles, you can only bring the units you had brought with you beforehand, and not magically drag them out of you♥♥♥♥♥like most RTS games. The only exception to this is the Skirmish game mode, which tries to make itself more similar to traditional RTS games.Another thing I like is that at the start of the battle, only a handful of units are on the battlefield. To bring in reinforcements, you must capture Reinforcement points, which will allow you to bring in more of your troops from orbit. If you have any that is. Normally for the defenders, they're stuck with what they had on the planet at the time, since in order to engage in ground combat, you must first clear out the Space around it. Not always though, as it's possible to sneak past the Orbital Defenses in certain instances.Space battles are similar in mechanics, except that(don't quote me on this yet) you aren't restricted to dropping(flying?) in reinforcements into Reinforcement Points. I'm still not very well versed in space battles yet, though. I've mostly played the tutorials and mostly ground combat in the campaign, and haven't done space battles as much. They're gorgeous though.Also, In space battles, the larger ships have whats called 'hardpoints', where you can target these smaller areas to disable/hamper the ships shields/weapons/etc.Both land and space have a decent amount of units, however it's not as high as some RTS games.All in all, I definately recommend this to any Strategy, RTS, or Star Wars fan. Especially if you're any combination of those three.

												If you like massive spacebattles in a Star Wars theme then this is one of the best games. You can play against AI or players on both the surface of many different planets or in space above them or in fields of asteroids. Empire or rebels the choice is yours, both have their own campaigns. If you add the "Republic at War" mod you may play as the Confederacy of Independent Systems or as the republic. Personally that mod has breath new life into the game for me, made me buy it in a non-CD version and play it some more. To be able to swarm the clone troopers with battledroids or hammer the CIS to submission with superior quality is both fun options. The AI in the campaign is not to be taken to lighlty on a higher diffidulty!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												Star Wars: Empire at War is not the greatest RTS I've ever played. Actually if this wasn't Star Wars related I'd probably not recommend this game. Empire at War is a game about conquering the galaxy as either the Empire or the Rebellion. Or some third party faction.Ground combat is not the best, I actually autoresolve most ground battles because the real fun is in the space combat commanding mighty Imperial II Class Star Destroyers and tearing through Rebel Escort Frigates.If you get this game I strongly encourage you to check out the two major mods for this game: Republic at War or Thrawn's Revenge. Repubic at War is a full conversion to be all about the Clone Wars and features characters from the TV show. I've never played it but I've heard good things about it. The other, Thrawn's Revenge is based on the expanded universe novels set after Return of the Jedi and it is a lot of fun. Thrawn's Revenge will add a lot more ships and unit types and heroes spanning the events from just after the Battle of Endor, through Grand Admiral Thrawn's Campaign, the reborn Emperor and that crisis, into Admiral Daala's time in command, the Black Fleet Crisis, and ends with the events of the Hand of Thrawn books covering about the 15-20 years between Return of the Jedi and the Pellaeon-Gavrisom Treaty.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												This game is really good.While it is loyal to how a good RTS game should be, you are not likely to have played something like this before. It is really an unique experience to command those rebel forces to destroy the death star and save the galaxy, to create a path of destruction with your imperial star destroyers or to corrupt your way through the galaxy with the Zann Consortium.The game has good graphics (for its age), lots of strategies to try and many different worlds, vehicles and military units with unique traits to discover. While it has a few flaws (the expansion bugs sometimes and the AI is way too predictable when you know how to play), they're not likely to disturb the gameplay too much.Honestly, I think this is an excellent game that is definetly worth trying.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												A top notch and well presentable RTS game, as well as an excellent star wars game, Empire at War is a great game for fans of rts and star wars fans, as it does a great job at preserving the elements and aesthetics of the original trilogy and it exapnding further by adding a few features from the Thrawn/Galatic Civil War trilogy with the forces of corruption expansion set.The space combat of the game alone should be more than enough to attract any space fanatic type of person, ground combat can be boring and can drag on due to the population limit (most units you can have is usually less than 10) and how large some ground maps can be. The game however suffers from a sketchy and out of tune ai, making the game quite unpleasant, espicially during space maps and your own units having a mind of their own and not being able to properly nagivate throughout the map.Another great selling point of the game is its modding capabilites. The modding community is currently alive and thriving due to the large amount of mods and upcoming mods for the game.
