content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												This is a great game for strategy fans, the fact it's Star Wars is just gravy. It's very similar in ways to Space 4X games, like Endless Space. Of course it's not that deep, but Empire at War is a nice mix of RTS and 4X. You Start out on the Galactic Map in most cases, in which there are numerous planets, each producing a certain amount of Credits, this games only resource/currency. You use Credits to purchase buildings on the planets you control, and Space Station upgrades once you purchase a Space Station in Orbit around the planet. You then build/recruit land units like tanks and infantry, or build spaceships ranging from small Fighter Ships, to large Capital Ships. You can create fleets containing Ships meant for battle, or just transport ships to carry troops. You can keep troops on your Battle ships, but I find it better to send the fighting ships first, THEN send the transports to take control of the ground.One thing I like is that in ground battles, you can only bring the units you had brought with you beforehand, and not magically drag them out of you♥♥♥♥♥like most RTS games. The only exception to this is the Skirmish game mode, which tries to make itself more similar to traditional RTS games.Another thing I like is that at the start of the battle, only a handful of units are on the battlefield. To bring in reinforcements, you must capture Reinforcement points, which will allow you to bring in more of your troops from orbit. If you have any that is. Normally for the defenders, they're stuck with what they had on the planet at the time, since in order to engage in ground combat, you must first clear out the Space around it. Not always though, as it's possible to sneak past the Orbital Defenses in certain instances.Space battles are similar in mechanics, except that(don't quote me on this yet) you aren't restricted to dropping(flying?) in reinforcements into Reinforcement Points. I'm still not very well versed in space battles yet, though. I've mostly played the tutorials and mostly ground combat in the campaign, and haven't done space battles as much. They're gorgeous though.Also, In space battles, the larger ships have whats called 'hardpoints', where you can target these smaller areas to disable/hamper the ships shields/weapons/etc.Both land and space have a decent amount of units, however it's not as high as some RTS games.All in all, I definately recommend this to any Strategy, RTS, or Star Wars fan. Especially if you're any combination of those three.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												Honestly this is a pretty good game. It has amazing details (especially in space) and my computer runs it just fine. The gameplay is fantastic other than the low unit cap in land battles i think its top notch. Now if your one of those people that likes to make giants armies and crush your opponents utterly, then maybe you should think twice about buying. The units caps are very low and very annoying, its makes it hard to crush your opponents and you just end up beating them. Not destroying or killing, just beating them. The new campaign with the Zann Consortium is nice, its not a "go there do that" campaign. It gives you an objective and lets you get there anyway you want(which is nice). So all and all, if you forget the unit cap i would say its a 8/10 game, and its the only star wars RTS game i have ever seen. So if you want to add it to your star wars collection then buy at will,  but i warn you, DO NOT BUY IF YOU WANT HUGE ARMIES! If you just want a mediocre force of soldiers go ahead and buy the game. Enjoy! (or don't)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												What a classic!Had this on disc for years but time to its toll and both the expanision and base discs got damaged to the point of not being read by any drive I put them in.After seeing this in the sale, I jumped at the chance and instantly bought it.Empire at War is a great pick-up and go game. It's gameplay is fast enough to not get boring quickly but it still maintains the challenge and pace of a true startegy game. If you have a beefy system, I'd recommend modding the game to allow for (virtually) unlimited population caps, especially in space battles. Nothing more fun than playing with friends and having a massive battles spanning across the entire map.Don't worry if your system isn't powerful either, my laptop (AMD E1 @ 1.35GHz) can handle pretty large battles with not a huge loss in framerate. Plus it runs it with max details and AA too so I can't complain too much.As I'm only a user of LAN multiplayer, I cannot comment on the Online support but I believe that programs such as gameranger may help get you playing over the internet.All in all. Do I recommend this game? Yes and no, while I find it fantastic myself, it's not going to be a showstopper for everyone. If you like Star Wars but are still unsure, wait until a sale and give it a go :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												Looks great. Lots of cool mods on the internet. The campaigns are fun, and so is the Consortium campaign. You can use strategy, or spam stuff which is easier. The Consortium is overpowered though. Its super annoying when playing against the Consortium.       The original Empire at War and the Forces of Corruption (FoC) addon are separate, which you can choose when you start the game. The original has the Rebel and Empire campaigns. FoC has the campaign for the Consortium. You can play single player modes on either version.        Playing galactic conquest as Rebels or Empire is terrible. Easy difficulty is too easy, Medium is too hard. Both sides will not give you any breathing room. Consortium can go to your planet and take over your level 5 space station just by being there. WTF? Is this a bug? Their military power is around 95%, while yours is around 30% - 60% if you try on easy mode. I have no choice but to do auto-resolve with a very large force when attacking Consortium on land because they spam tanks and long range torpedoes which can wipe out anything you throw at them.       You can control the super star destroyer, Executor, but only in galactic conquest. The icon looks like Darth Vader. In space, Vader is the Executor. On land Vader is himself ofcourse. You can use the 2nd Death Star which has the ability to destroy any enemy ship, but only in galactic conquest.New heroes: Luke, Yoda, Garm Bel Iblis and his huge hover tank, the Arc Hammer factory ship, Admiral Thrawn, Dark side witch, IG-88, Bossk, Tyber Zann, Urai. Kyle and Mara are removed.       Dark troopers phase 1 - 3, new tie fighters, over powered Consortium capitol ships with big guns and stealth (seriously, Consortium capitol ships are OP), mon cal frigate with cluster bombs, ewoks with bombs strapped to them..., rancors, droidekas. Rebels have not changed much because they already have more units than Empire.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												Amazing Game! Halo Wars, but in a Star Wars universe. You are able to, from a bird's eye view, direct your space and land conquests, on a galactic scale, and crush your enemies. Although multiplayer is no longer active through Game Spy, you can use gameranger or LAN(which I find much more fun) to achieve a great multiplayer expierence. If single player is your gam then you can attempt Galactic Conquest and take over all 100+ Planets with epic space and lnd battles as you research new technologies starting with small aclamators and moving up to Venators and the Death Star! And if you don't want to play Galactic Civil War era, then get the Mod: Republic At War and install it to play the Clone Wars. This mod is well made, and basically a game in its own. Pros: - The star wars strategy game everyone has been searching for- AI is programmed very well for being an older game- "Battlecam" (spacebar) to watch your battles from a ships perspective- Accurate compared to movies/books (Rebels are horribly nerfed compared to the Empire which is exactly how it is in the movies, however this does not mean the rebels can not win!)- Republic At War Mod is accurate as well to where the CIS can outgun the Republic, however the Republic has better firepowerCons: - Lag. This is an oldgame so it can not take advantage as advanced CPUs and GPUs. Frame lag is terrible when a lot of ships have entered the game (Probably why it is limited to a certain amount of people to be landed) - White screen when changing graphics. Reboot necessary to have changed take affect. - No native support for multiplayer since gamespy shutdown. :( The one ting no star wars game developer has created yet was basically space engineers but in a star wars universe. I really would like to pilot my venator in firts person and have seamless planet entry (no loading as soon as you enter a planet).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												Oi, I wanted to love this game I really did.  Ok First things first.  Yes it's a big galaxy strategy game of Star wars, you can build fleets and armies, have land and space battles, build star destroyers etc, it's all there.BUT: When I'm playing it I'm thinking, for every thing the game does well, there's two things that crop up that make me think, 'rebellion did this better six years earlier'.1)You get limited 'command points' so that the biggest battle you get is about 5 star destroyers... if you have 20, fine, they come in one at a time as reinforcements.2) Ships repair automatically, so if you cripple a ship in a hit and fade mission, eg, you play as rebels, fly in blast a big star destroyer, fly out then your main fleet comes in just after, literally 1 second can transpire, which represents maybe 1/12 of a galactic day, and that ship will be completely fixed.  So anything you don't destroy is immediately repaired.  That seems like basic logic has gone WAY out the window.3) You can not sabotage anything, you can only steal technology as the rebels, so usig spec forces or whatever doesn't come into it all.4) Ground battles are  alittle repetitive, and if for eg, you take over a planet, you can't build defences on the ground level until a battle starts... WHAT THE HELL! So eg you can build BIG things like Ion cannons or shields for the planet, but little 'build pads' for local defences to help you shoot down AT-AT's or whatever can't be built until an invading army arrives... what was my army doing for the six months I held that planet, just standing there? Then they go.. 'oh right, the enemy is landing, maybe we shouldn't have been just giving each other piggy back rides this whole time...'These might sound niggly as problems, and  they are, but they and a few more I wont mention REALLy pile up to hold the game back from being great. The story is paper thin, leads up to the destruction of the 1st death star in star wars 1977.THE EXPANSION PACK:In short, it fixes about three little problems, much improved story campaign, you can now sabotage and do things like that BUT ONLY WITH THE NEW TEAM, but the issues above are still largely present.And when you play games with all 3 teams (ie NOT the campaign) You can see how balance was not an issue for the developers.The new team, the pirates are SO overpowered and will absolutely cripple the rebs and imps, so play as them or get angry, that's your choices.So overall, yes I do recommend it, you can see by my hours played that I still gave it a go, and the expansion definitely improves the game enough to give it some reply value. ( I got a MOD with some maps, so I could play the expansion on old maps WITHOUT the new pirate team, thus it wasn't so unabalanced, but could play with the new features, ships etc)Flying into battle with the Death Star II and Vader's super star destroyer with another 4/5 star destroyers is still very enjoyable. So worth a play, but beware its drawbacks.

												I have played this game for a long time since before I got steam, To this day it's one of the best RTS games out there. Vanilla game is pretty lame with bad voice acting in some parts but all in all a solid game. I want to review this game with the Thrawn Mod however.The good: Even to todays standards with the Thrawn mod ( can't think of the legit name I got it on moddb) are pretty sweet.Lots and Lots of units space and land.Fighting in space then fighting on the planet below I'm still looking for an RTS that can duplicate this.It's Star wars.The Bad: No veterancyEvery other Star Destroyer is Named the Alecto.Very dated (not bad persay but I would love it if Disney greenlit a remake of this with more planets, a cover system for infantry and garrisonable buildings. Think Wargame, Men of War and Star Wars had a threesome and the love child would be this game) If you're a fan oF Star Wars and want to invade the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of some planets as the Empire buy this game now.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												This is my favorite Star Wars game. I remember playing this as a young child. Star Wars: Empire at War is a RTS (Real Time Strategy) game. You are able to chose to play as the Rebel Alliance, and bring peace to the galaxy, or as the mighty Empire, and take over the galaxy. You are given command of squadrons of soldiers, and you can increase the number of soldiers you have and use different units such as tanks or heavy soldiers, etc. Multiplayer doesn't work anymore, sadly, but you can try it with Tuungle. The graphics are not up to shape, but again, this is an old game.  You can play the campaign which has quite the engaging story to it, especially the "Forces of Corruption" DLC. There is no steam workshop attatched, but with some decent researching on Youtube and websites such as ModDB, you can play the game with mods. If you love Star Wars and RTS games, especially old style ones, this game is for you.

Posted: April 1, 2015
												An invigorating taste on the StarWars franchise, putting you as a commander, on ethier side. Its an incredible RTS game that feels great as you manage a small economy, unit cap, capturing planets and creating installations. What sets it apart from other StarWars games is that you can battle in space and ground as well as managing planetary defenses and creating ground troops for planatary assults. This may all seem confunsisng at first but I suggest running throught the tutorial then the campaign for beginners.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												might not be the best rts but its definatly a good star wars gamecommand your armies to take over the galaxy     pretty straight forwardwhats special about this is you got two forms of combat, land and space which really makes capturing a planet a process since you have to get both to have full control of the planet,though you can send smaller units, particularly heros and you wont have to deal with the space battleunits are broken up into infantry\fighters, light vehicles\small ships, artillary (or what would be called glass cannons), heavy vehicles\big ships and heros heros are pretty self explanetory, the characters you know can fight on ground battles and some in space, alot of them can land on planets undetected and have special abilities, once a hero dies they will recharge before they can be brought back in againin the galactic modes you can build structures on planets that allow you to build units, get upgrades, etcevery planet can build a space station which like some ground stuctures provides free garrison units when the planet  is attackedships and space stations are build up of hard points, hard points normally contain various types of turrets, shields, hangers, engines and special weapons, i thought this was really cool considering you can focus your forces on the most important hard point similar to how you attack the enemy ships engines, bridge, communication and life support in star wars battlefront 2 however these hardpoints contributes to the ships fuction and if they are destroyed they are gone for the rest of the battle (ex your engines are destroyed you go really slow, your shields are destroyed you have no shields) one of the things that i disliked about the game is that you can auto result a battle which will automaticly complete the battle and show you the results the only problem is it decreases your winning chances signifgantly, auto battle is only a viable option when you want to give up a planet but want to take some forces with you but sometimes it wont even do that and if you do win you will get signifigant losessome units arent even properly balancedanother thing is that the galatic conquests maps are always so split aparti enjoy the mode the most when you start off on less than 6 planets and have to beef up your defenses before going on the offenses, the problem is either your planets are two and far apart or you have too many planets and not nearly enough time or money to prepare your planets i wish there where more galactic conquests though because skrimish is well skrimish and campagin is obviously very directedbut then again you can always download custom ones so thats not a big deali highly suggest getting the republic at war mod it really adds alotall and all its a enjoyable rts but not perfect

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												Excellent RTS. Battles are fun and dinamyc and the galactic conquest mode depicts the star wars universe pretty accuratly. The exapansion is also a lot of fun. It adds a playable faction with unique units and buildings and adds a few units to the republic's roster and the rebel roster. This game is set in the starwars universe in the context of the first trilogy.  If you are interested in playing the clone wars there is an overall mod called Republic at War (RaW). This mod is perhaps the greatests overall mod I have seen in a video game.  It is even closer to the star wars universe than the base game. You can play as the confederacy fielding a variety of droids and massive spaceships. Or the rebublic using battalions of clones recruited straight from kamino. This game is worh getting just for the expansion. I find it better than the base game anyways.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												7/10I love this game so why 7/10? Let me tell you... Corruption!!! Why isn't there some kind of tech or what ever to help control this super annoying feature? Many fan boys have complained about this and yet nothing was ever done. Two: No one is faster than the computer so why can't the player start to move their units on the campaign map in pause or during the start of a battle? I find some times I go from battle to battle without being able to react to anything on the campaign map. Just give me 1/2 a second to move my units. Good Lord! And, this is a big one, multiplayer isn't supported anymore!!!! WTF!?!?Well, that was my two cents. Oh and don't expect updates with any of Petroglyph or LucasArts' games. Won't ever happen because they don't think they make money from fixing released games. Yet they still sell them and at full price almost ***6 YEARS*** later! humm? Shame on you!! If they would fix these three things I could recommend getting this game at full price of $20 but they won't so get it on sale for under $10 or even $5.

Posted: January 11, 2016
												¿Te gusta Star Wars?Compralo.¿Te gustan los RTS?Compralo.¿Te gusta el imperio?Compralo.¿Te gustan los mods?Compralo.¿Te gusta? Compralo Bueno, aqui el verdadero analisisStar Wars: Empire at War GOLD PACK es un pack que incluye el juego original y el DLC que implementa varias mejoras al juego, tales como una nueva faccion, Nuevas unidades, nuevas naves, nueva historia, y nuevos personajes.FoC es un juego relativamente facil de modificar, por lo que existen varios mods como Republic At War, Battlefront Commander, The Clone Wars 4.0 entre varios otros que tengo instalados.Estos mods implementan mejoras graficas, muchas mas y mejores unidades y nuevas eras.El juego es realmente muy entretenido, pienso jugar 200 horas mas de las que llevo actualmente. Ahora que he terminado con el analisis.Compralo.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												Remember playing this game for hours a few times, its very imperium galactica 2 meets star wars, which is why i like it so much, because both of them are alike in a lot of ways.While i like playing this game a lot, i think it would be best if it were played in compatibility mode, playing it from win 7 i am having frequent issues with the game bugging in graphics or glitching during specific moments like the ui disappearing on me, including the planet names and fleet icons. frequently needing to shut the game down and start it up again in order to cure the problem. the latest trouble i have run across is starting the empire campaign, you get the initial planets plus taris and everything else is locked out, but from thyferra or abragado to taris, it is not accessible to be reached. this is just after the first mission on the empire side.graphics are now more dated then games on more modern standards, but that does not matter too much. as long as the game is fun and engaging, it is enough.Edit: I wouldnt recommend the expansion though, the first hit impression wasnt good, and after now playing a number of hours on it, i do not like it; the auto resolve ground fight more often than not end up with losses mounting, the single player campaign isnt that accessible and the balance is woeful, your ground forces just die all too easily. this becomes a problem when the ai takes a few swamp speeders to your landing zone as you are landing forces. within 10 seconds you would of lost 3/4 of your standing forces before you can get any control of the units to attack back which more often than not, happens. so while the EAW gold i would recommend, the expansion is something i would not recommend.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Space Battles are pretty nice, though rather limited in scope. Quick paced economy keeps things brisk and the reinforcement mechanic is perfect. Land Battles aren't my thing: I'd rather just play Star Wars Battlegrounds, it's deeper and suits my turtle tactics much more. The AI is somewhat disappointing, but I suppose I've come to expect that at this point from RTS games. Haven't even tried the campaign, since a) it's Star Wars, I already know the canon and b) it just... doesn't interest me. Not a great excuse, I suppose, for leaving the game "unfinished".If the game were exclusively "Space Battle" focused, I'd love it, but as it is, it's okay.Dunno who thought the Proton Torpedo Spamming Frigates were a good idea, but that person needs to get kicked in the crotch... talk about OP.Other than that, edit an .xml to boost the pop cap, make a map in the editor (downloaded seperately, google it), and have at! It can be great fun!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Easily got over 500 hours on the old disk version because its just so damn good, Galactic Conquest will keep you entertained for hours just like the campaign will. Skrimish matches are also real fun when you have a 2v2 Hard. When you get bored of the base game you can then hop on over to Moddb and get some amazing mods like Republic At War, Rise of the Mandalorians, Empire at War : RE and a ton more. If you have friends with the same game and mods you can play against or with them on Tunngle, Game Ranger or Evolve, and also play custom maps.This game gets a 10/10 from me simply because it made you feel like you were in the Star Wars universe, Especially when there are massive space battles going on, Lasers everywhere, TIE's and X-Wings dog fighting, Star Destroyers and Mon Calamaries blasting eachother to peices.You will buy this game.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Probably by far one of my favorite RTS's to this date, and it came out around 2004.The space battles are incredible. You actually have to think about the maneuvers of your ships as well as their strengths and weaknesses.Land battles are some times lacking, the AI is pretty smart in this game so watch out, they will rush you.The only thing that I dislike about the game is that some times, escpecially the Rebels (Scum that they are), the AI will research to the point they get that one good unit, and spam it to high hell. Get used to seeing mutiples of the same unit in armies towards the end game.Been playing with Zann's boys mostly, favorite faction to date. (MANDALORIANS!) Their bonus, as well as the bonus added into the expansion pack, are perfect.And if you love star wars, you WILL love this. I guarantee it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Honestly, it doesn't seem like this game came out 5 years ago. This is one of my favorite RTS's of all time, right next to AoE. The dual plane RTS mechanic is what makes this game a great balance between combat and building your empire. I have yet to replay  through the story, but I recall it being really fun and quite long (If you consider the different story lines just one campaign, it is even longer). Also, being able to refine and hone in your ground combat skills in the skirmish mode is very helpful, since you don't have to initiate an extensive galactic conquest match. Since I don't want to have a wall of text, nor feel like making an in depth review, just buy this game. Here is a synopsis of why you should:+ Star Wars+ Really great space battles+ Fun ground battles+Great sounds and sound track+ A good learning curve; this game can appeal to casual gamers as well as hardend RTS players. It just depends on how much time you want to put into the game, and if you want a challenge (the CPU opponents can get pretty feisty lol)+ A plethora of units from the entire Star Wars galaxy + The cinematic view is cool+ Space battles in particular are super fun to just sit back and watch. Something about them lasers...Really the only con(s) would be- Price. But the game gives you so much content for a fraction of the cost of a big name companies would charge. That said, I'd suggest getting it on sale if you still have reservations about buying it- Graphics. The game is 5 years old, what do you expect? Even so, it really isn't that bad maxed out, it actually looks quite good for its age! All in all, great game. I have yet to find anything bad/wrong about the game. 10/10EDIT:I've since played throught the campaign, and its really fun. Not necessarily note worthy story telling, and there isn't much of a plot, but I still found it entertaining to play through. It isn't as long as I recalled, being that it took me ~5hrs and I was purposely taking my time.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												This is one of my favorite games ever. The Space combat is hands down the most enjoyable part of this game and it feels like I'm partcipating in a Star Wars space battle. The Ground combat is a very slow and does not feel very natural it is very hard to control anything. While there is alot in the base game and its expansion Forces of Corruption the real fun comes with the insane amount of mods that the community has created for it. They come in many ways for example if you love just the base game but wanted more ships and ground units then getting Absolute corruption which adds countless ships to each side and adds units to ground combat to make it less annoying. However if you want a total conversion then there are two mods I would point to, they are Republic at War and Thrawn's Revenge. They each put the game into different Eras of Star Wars and do very unique things to the game that makes it feel completly different. This is one of the best Star Wars games that you can get right now.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												Had to defend my lonely level 2 space station on Kessel from several Rebel corvettes and fighters. I was tempted to click Auto-Resolve, but I gave it a try. Might as well lose with honor. I fight the corvettes off valiantly and the fighters don't put a dent in the shielding. The few squads of fighters I had from the station's hangar bay helped, but only for some extra firepower. They quickly died.Then, a wonderful voice came over the communications system. "Reinforcements en route."I glanced near my space station. Sure enough, 3 Tartan Patrol cruisers came in from hyperspace and instantly fired upon the foe. The rebel fleet fought and fought, but alas, they did not succeed.I just won an impossible battle. Without reinforcements, I would've surely died.10/10

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												It is a fantastic game, I would highly recommend it. Especially to any Star Wars fans out there.However the game has one flaw on steam, the launching of the expansion (that steam thinks is a DLC) doesn't work properly. Therefore you must right click the Star Wars: Empire at War Gold pack, open properties, set launch options and type in the following: swfoc MODPATH=Mods\When you now click launch FoC (Forces of Corruption), it will now correctly launch Foc instead of Eaw (The basic game, Empire at War). I hope this will help new players of the game that encounter this problem. I also wish you a fun time with the title, and don't forget to check out the mods. There are several set in the era after the original trilogy (Thrawn's Revenge, Awakening of the Rebellion) and quite a few set in The Clone Wars era (The Clone Wars, Republic At War).Have fun, and may the force be with you.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												It was hard to not give this game a 'not recommend' because of nostalgia and the fact that it is an okay game, that being said there are quite a few problems with it. Mostly they are just balencing issues with some of the units being far too overpowered or weak. The biggest issues are in the conquest mode with the Zann Consortimum being unbalenced ("Your structure on Coruscant has been destroyed! Your structure on Kessel has been destroyed! Your structure on..." so on and so forth), you can hear enemy fleets approaching because of the massive alert it gives you but you can't see where they are moving or where they are attacking just that they are attacking so most battles end up like 1 battlestation and a frigate against an entire fleet (IT ENDS PRETTY FAST) also the "autoresolve" function hates you if you have a army (or fleet) that is one of everything you will win most battles by autoresolving because of a countering system that the autoresolve goes through, on the other side of that though if you just spam only fighters like the A wing prepare your♥♥♥♥♥♥(Brother made 500 A-wings I was it was stupid he kills entire fleets with them, I stand corrected apparently it was genius). But for a game it's really fun it is, and the space battles have the cool function of shooting at specfic parts of ships which makes for interesting gameplay. The conquest and land battles are fairly bland though as nothing much happens other than those small fast ending battles and land battles are just... well boring. But it is definatly fun to play and I remember why I enjoyed it as a little one.

If you love Star Wars RTS games, or you are a Star Wars fan I do reccomend this game, but if you are a hardcore RTS player I do not reccomend this game Score:5-6/10

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												It was hard to not give this game a 'not recommend' because of nostalgia and the fact that it is an okay game, that being said there are quite a few problems with it. Mostly they are just balencing issues with some of the units being far too overpowered or weak. The biggest issues are in the conquest mode with the Zann Consortimum being unbalenced ("Your structure on Coruscant has been destroyed! Your structure on Kessel has been destroyed! Your structure on..." so on and so forth), you can hear enemy fleets approaching because of the massive alert it gives you but you can't see where they are moving or where they are attacking just that they are attacking so most battles end up like 1 battlestation and a frigate against an entire fleet (IT ENDS PRETTY FAST) also the "autoresolve" function hates you if you have a army (or fleet) that is one of everything you will win most battles by autoresolving because of a countering system that the autoresolve goes through, on the other side of that though if you just spam only fighters like the A wing prepare your♥♥♥♥♥♥(Brother made 500 A-wings I was it was stupid he kills entire fleets with them, I stand corrected apparently it was genius). But for a game it's really fun it is, and the space battles have the cool function of shooting at specfic parts of ships which makes for interesting gameplay. The conquest and land battles are fairly bland though as nothing much happens other than those small fast ending battles and land battles are just... well boring. But it is definatly fun to play and I remember why I enjoyed it as a little one.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												/!\CAUTION/!\ I have a lot of nostalgia towards this game. I don't know if Nostalgia is blinding my judgement or not!Star Wars: Empire at War is a Real Time Strategy (RTS) game set in the Star Wars universe. It got an expansion pack which expands the game a lot.Good things:-The main game has 2 campaigns, 2 factions, and a lot of planet to play with. Meaning a lot of different ways to win/lose.-Battles on Foot AND in space. And in the WHOLE FREAKING GALAXY.-Newcomer friendly. This game got me into strategy, and seeing as how I f*cking love this genre, it's a VERY good thing.-It's about the Galactic Civil War. Meaning you get to play as DARTH VADER.-The expansion packs adds a 3rd campagin, faction, and a dozen of planets.-With the expansion pack, you get to chose your base's layout. This may not seem like a huge thing, but it can be important depending on your playstyle.-You get to use THE DEATH STAR(s).-The 3rd Faction has Destroyer Droids. Nuff' said.Bad things:-This game's graphics aged REALLY badly.-It's set in the Galactic Civil War. Meaning you don't get to play as CRISTOPHER LEE (R.I.P.).-Boba Fett is Empire only. Even with the 3rd Faction.-The Death Star may make your game crash. (That's not a good thing in case you're wondering)-If you don't have the Expansion Pack, Luke is Space only. And with the Expansion Pack, he's on foot only.-The main game has cinematics in case you lose/win. The Expansion Pack doesn't. Because F*ck you.

												Loved this game as a kid, then my computer aged into a toaster and was not able to play it anymore. 9 years later I see it on sale on steam and i lose my marbles. I dowload the game and logged 66 hours in 2 weeks. Would definitely reccomend to anyone who loves star warsPros:   Space battles are epic   Han is still alive    No Jar Jar Binks   Awesome mods on the internet but can be a pain to install (ex. Republic at War}   Correctly using things instead of telling everyone to attack the same thing can allow you to pull          victorys out of thin air   An interesting campaign   Mass Genocide now made possibleCons:   land battles are somewhat boring and difficult   Can be a hard game if you dont know what you are doing   Modding isnt as easy as it could be   No Jar Jar Binks to kill in game (but can wipe out gungan race) First Quality game 11/10 Would waste my life on for a third time

												This is an average RTS with some good space battles and not so good land battles. If you are Star Wars fun try it, otherwise don't. Space battles are good but there are some others game which do things better. Game implements some stuff from Star Wars universe quite well but on the other hand there are some thing which should feel like Star Wars but they just don't.  Forces of Corruption is decent expansion which adds some new space and land units, and new faction. I recommend you to download mod which resize all ships to real scale from the movies and canon. content:
Posted: February 20
												This game is a must for strategy and Star Wars fans, While the base game (and FoC) are great and fun games in their own right, the real reason this stands out is the amazing mods the community has made. Here are two I would highly reccomend.Republic at War: Puts you in th clone wars era, difficulty is definately raised here, somewhat unbalanced but really doesn't take away from the experience.Thrawns Revenge: This is my personal favorite for many different reasons, There 5(or 6?) factions and most of them are playable, It adds a metric assload of new units (Both space and ground), its very well balanced and challenging, and it changes up the combat in some neat and good ways.

												Let me just say this, for what I paid to buy this game, $5.99. I feel like I nearly stole this game. I mean sure it borrows peices from other games and other games have borrowed from it (Warhammer 40,000) but it really is it's own thing. I highly recommend if on sale, which is not to say its' not worth 20 but concidering its age, a price drop is just what I needed to say yes and now to tell other people, yes its worth buying!

content:
Posted: January 1
												Having completed all three campaigns and one game of conquest my worst fears are confirmed. EAW is an RTS hybrid that tries to be many things but is tripped by technical issues, bad design decisions and a clear lack of testing. The end result is a game that is mediocre at best and only held together by the magic glue that is Star Wars. Only recommended for fans who are willing to suck on a lollypop made out of pure salt just because it's shaped like Darth Vader's helmet.+Authentic Star Wars music and sound effects that leave nothing to be desired. Sometimes even the voice acting is surprisingly good+Graphics seem fairly timeless with some space battle effects still looking pretty sweet+Space battles are fun most of the time+Asymmetric factions (Empire has bigger ships with free fighters, Alliance has better fighters that require no carriers etc.)+Multiple campaigns and conquest mode scenarios+Dropping the screen filling Executor in the middle of a battle for the first time should make any nerds inner fascist climax immediately-Doesn't seem to play nice with Win10 and has no borderless window support. If played fullscreen while Alt-Tabing can put your Windows in a state where you have to reboot to get anything done. I recommend running it in a maximized window instead.-Game breaking bugs include disappearing critical characters, inability to task units to campaign critical missions, disappearing units etc. These issues can be somewhat circumvented with furious saving. Always save to a new file!-A multitude of UX issues that range from fighters needlessly blocking capital ships from selection to the way save files are handled: latest saves don't always show up first, save files take too much space etc.-AI blatantly cheats both by its very nature and also seems to gain scripted fleets out of nowhere for the campaigns-AI sometimes just freezes and does nothing with its ships in battle-Unit AI is atrocious and does not seem to do any target prioritization whatsoever for any attacks. Pathfinding gets progressively worse with unit size to the point where units like AT-ATs, artillery units and Star Destroyers sometimes require near constant micromanaging so that they move the way you need-Being unable to assign any movement orders on the galactic map in pause mode makes no sense-Forces of Corruption doesn't integrate to the main game and is actually a separate game that feels like it was cheaply hacked together in a hurry-While the original EaW is somewhat balanced, the Consortium faction in FoC is completely out of whack and seems to have the best in almost everything in addition to their frustrating corruption mechanic that requires constant fiddling especially from the opponents-Ground battles are usually horrendously repetitive and tedious-Battles can be autoresolved, but the logic for resolving them is completely ludicrous and can lead to massive casualties even if the opponent doesn't actually have any chance of fighting back-Very limited amount of units and ships in a battle at any given time (for example, you can have 6 Imperial class Star Destroyers if you have almost nothing else) and the rest have to be drip-fed into the battle as reinforcements when previous units are destroyed-Player can't choose which units enter a battle first in EaW (mostly fixed in FoC though)-Flying units can't actually fly over many obstacles in ground battles-Some of the writing and voice acting is very cringeworthy especially in FoC. A few characters also use quotes from the movies to a ridiculous degree even for fanservice-The Alliance can commit genocide without any issues and can actually get more funds from it

content:
Posted: January 7
												If you love Star Wars and the entire franchise, then that is absolutely wonderful; however, this Star Wars RTS game doesn't feel like a true RTS. It lacks that simple enjoyment that you get when playing similiar games like Warcraft, Age of Empires or Total War. It just lacks those features and replaces them with a complete automated system. You can't place your own buildings where you would like them, they are done for you. Getting resources? Automatically done. All you do is upgrade and build troops while conducting a small micro deployment here and there in terms of reinforcements. I've seen far much better with competitors, save your time and money. Just stick with the non-gaming franchise and go watch the movies and collect memorabilia! I didn't enjoy this game and regret buying it!

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												I really like the game, but there are 3 major things that make me mad about the game, the difficulty, the Corruption, and the lack of maps. I will explain the three in this review.The difficulty has a major jump of difference from normal to hard. Normal being super easy if you can build up and defend yourself for like 50 days and hard being just a pure ♥♥♥♥ing headache. The Empire and Corruption just team on me on hard and just keep on sending excesively huge armadas just like 5 days in the game. And it's so hard to spam out mining facilities when A. they're being blown up and B. you have to make a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of space units to defend. The Corruption is horrifically overpowered. Being able to "Corrupt" plants. After being corrupted, you can either slip through the planet's defences and go to another enemy planet, or blow up ground structures. On hard, the Corruption will pretty much just destroy a building every oppertunity they have. Making it difficult to make an economy because your mining facilities are being blown up. Not to mention the fact that it is QUITE expensive to remove it unless you have a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of planets.The lack of maps make it just boring to play, they don't even seem to be that well made. Like in Equal Footing all of the factions' worlds were spread out and difficult to defend UNLESS you're Corruption. tl;dr unless you like a challenge, (don't play corruption in galactic conquest) You will propubly find some aspects of this game a pain. (Oh and I stupidly pressed "press this if you got this game for free". This is not part of the review.

number of helpful: 18 of 53 people (34%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												Empire at War is probably the Star Wars' most serious foray into the strategy genre, and I hate to say it's mixed at best. While the battlescapes make for some really impressive visuals, the game falls flat on its face on the tactical map.It's one of the worst I've ever seen in a strategy game. It's real time with a pause, which wouldn't be an issue execpt the game refuses to let you make any meaningful orders while paused. It will only be an hour or so before you started getting bombarded with battle prompts (which you can autoresolve) back-to-back, and it just becomes completely unmanagable as your attention is constantly divided. It seriously plays like a turn-based system that was retooled to realtime at the very last second, and its shows. I cannot understate how frustrating it is to deal with. And while the battlescape is fun to play on, it also has issues. Pathfinding for you or the AI is atrocious, and you'll often have to bear ships taking a full minute to turn around when they could have just moved forward. On top of some pretty awful unit balance, battles are always completely lopsided and predictable. Do not get this on anything but the cheapest of sales. The cool battles might draw you in, but the game turns into a slog very, very quickly.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												The original is a surprising rts - simple-looking but deceptively deep and most definitely playable. Excellent job particularly in space battles of capturing the feel of Star Wars. Regrettably, network play is completely inert in this release... one would have hoped some effort to facilitate Steam net play would have been made, but no. Even virtual networks seem to fail to get multiplayer up & running. Forces Of Corruption is exactly that: an imbalanced force that corrupts the integrity of the base game. The new faction itself is horrifically overpowered making Imperials and Rebels alike look feeble. Silly. Ignoring that expansion pack, if Empire At War were ever repaired, it would be worthy.

number of helpful: 5 of 25 people (20%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												TL:DR - If you're looking for a more casual RTS - This isn't it.So, I can see how this would be something many people could like. It is Star Wars after all. But after playing for a good 5 hours, I can tell that this is not a Star Wars game that I like. Which is very rare for me. My experience with it so far has been pretty horrendous, mainly through seemingly cheating AI mechanics and sudden difficulty spikes. Naturally, I was playing on Easy, and I'm not great at RTS, but I sort of assumed it would be more like C&C where you would have time to build up your forces and then assualt the enemy. Its not like that at all. My experiences come from C&C Red Alert and Generals and I've also played a fair amount of Shogun Total War. My issue I feel is that the time scale of the game literally leaves you behind within 30 seconds. In Galactic CQ, I am frequently being raided and out-gunned within the first 5 minutes of play. The AI steam rolls as it doesn't seem to be confined to the amount of actions a human could physically decide upon and take. The AI is so precise and clinical in its processes, that within the first 5 Galactic days, the Rebellion already has amased an economy 5 times greater than my own. I've been through forums and such and there seems to be no real answers about why this game is so different in play style to C&C or Shogun. But I feel its the fact that the AI moves so fast.Personally I was looking for a more casual Star Wars C&C clone. This is not what this game is, unless you're already good at such game. I feel like I would have enjoyed it more if I had time to learn and not be swept off the game board almost immeditly by huge fleets which can't physically have been created with only a starting credit cap if 5K. Inexperience is also a deciding factor. The tutorials are decent, but they don't really provide you with the load of how much you have to do and organise. Also, the reinforcement mechanic which the player is forced to use, but the AI can happily spawn tanks etc against you... is just broken. Also, don't bother playing the expansion. The 3rd faction is so OP that there is literally no point, unless you like seeing all of your "owned" worlds, completely corrupted and leeched within 30 seconds.Just glad I bought it on sale. If we consider £1 for 1 hour of play-time, I'd say the game at least achieved that.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Horribly unbalanced and dated game.While the graphics may look appealing, even today, the gameplay is an entirely different story. Both on land and space battles, there are units and certain aspects of different factions that you can exploit to garantee a win. If you decide to play a conquest game, beware when fighting against the Empire. If they are able to build a death star, it can quickly decimate the areas you control. When defending against it in space, you will have a couple of minutes to try and destroy every last space craft the enemy has, before they'll be able to use the death star to instantly destory your space station or planet, forcing you to lose the battle. The Consortium is just as bad. While they have most of the cool and fun to use units, all of their units are designed to ignore your units shields, auto kill any fighters you have, etc. while they have individually shielded structures, and gain bonuses to what really matters (space station wise), hard points.Most larger ships and space stations have things called 'hard points', such as turbo lasers, ion canons, proton torpedos, engines, and shields. Once destroyed, they can not be recovered. While the Empire and Rebels usually can increase their shield strength or firepower, the Consortium increases the armor on their space stations hardpoints. Why this is so important is because each faction has at least one or two units that can bypass shields, usually missile ships or bombers, so shields aren't entirely important to bolster. Being able to better defend your hard points is a little more effective. As for on the ground, both the empire and rebellion have a unit that can fly, a special, unique kind of unit that ignores most rules of combat. Bolstering incredibly high mobility and decent firepower, they can skip the ground combat and go right for the enemies base. With a large enough force, most units wouldn't be able to shoot them down, while you quickly wittle away at their forces and structures. Seriously, they are just that powerful. This doesn't mean I hate the concept of this game. Rather, I hate how little thought and care was put into the game. It had the potential to be so much better, and I would love to see someone try and remake the game. I strongly recommend not buying the game for more than $6.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												Sluggish controls, tactical map unit caps, and a real time macrostrategic map of the galaxy make this a pain. Yes, there's a pause button on the galactic map, but you can't do anything while paused like move fleets or build units. It only works on the tactical map. Also, some of the scenario maps seem glitched on tech levels. If you go to advanced settings and reduce the starting tech level while playing on hard, then you start with reduced technology but the computer starts with regular technology. Having X Wings, Y Wings, and basic frigates doesn't really match top of the line Imperial Star Destroyers.There's also no hold position command. You can tell units to stop, but it's very easy to lure or get lured, especially when units won't respond instantly after being lured. This creates a very annoying situation where rocket infantry wreck light tanks, anti-infantry vehicles wreck light infantry, and aircraft become pointless (although aircraft dominate easily until AA weapons are around). In space, it means fighters and bombers won't withdraw from cruisers, and larger ships that are slightly misoriented beacuse they advanced two inches too far take forever to turn around.The game really isn't that bad, but it's like they choked it for no good reason and ruined the experience. If the units were responsive, tactical map unit caps didn't exist, the galactic map was turn based instead of real time, and the pause button let you issue orders while paused, then this would be an easy thumbs up. I have no idea why they ruined their own game with arbitrary restrictions.

number of helpful: 3 of 21 people (14%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												I loved Galactic Battlegrounds and have enjoyed many others in the same genre, like C&C, AOE, etc.I feed stupid for saying it, but this was too difficult for me.  The first bit of the tutorial was a breeze, but as soon as the second one started, I was lost.  Drag this there.  Zoom in.  Click that.  I followed what I was told to do, but didn't have much comprehension as to why.  There was too much information given to me in that second tutorial and I was unable to absorb it in order to use that knowledge in-game.I skipped the rest of the tutorials and started a campaign (on easy) to see how much the information on the second tutorial impinged on the game.  On the second part of the campaign, I was presented with the world map - right there, I was lost.  I dragged R2-D2 onto the planet I was meant to, and did the same for a couple of troops, but when I zoomed in to that planet, it said the battle was starting so onto the ground I went.  Moved right a little while and found a laser turret, quickly followed by more troops than I had.  Didn't last long before I was wiped out.  The commentary said to call for reinforcements but I'd no idea how to do that.Should I have dragged more troops on before getting to the planet?  I understand that Empire at War can't just be more of the same that was presented in Galactic Battlegrounds, but this was too much of a departure/advancement for me.  I'd far rather be put on the planet and have to build my base before encountering the turret and troops - I could then have built more if needs be.Given I'm fine with other similar games, I blame the tutorial.  If it was anything like the one in C&C Red Alert 3, it could impart as much new information as it needed to without the user feeling lost.  I understand I'm in the minority here given 93% of users recommend this - perhaps if I sat with one of them and have them walk me though the basics, I'd have a better chance of enjoying this title, but as it is, I'm sadly deleting it in frustration.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												Terrible.  Before the expansion, Empire at War was a below average strategy/rts game that I went ahead and played sometimes anyway because it managed to pretty faithfully create a Star Wars feel.Then I bought Gold to get the expansion, even though I didn't enjoy the original very much.  I was thinking I would get some more "hero" characters and maybe the new faction would be nice.  The new faction is not nice.  Almost nothing that comes with the expansion is from Star Wars--most of the hero units you get are characters that I guess came from Expanded Universe or one of the animated series, or maybe created originally for the game.  Whatever they are, new hero units are terrible.  They don't fit with the original character and stand out like a fist-full of sore thumbs.Why fill my Rebel Alliance hero roster with all these off-brand characters such as "Garm Bel Iblis" when you still haven't added a Princess Leia character?  The new faction is the worst.  The Zann Consortium--a criminal empire, is made up almost entirely of "Not from Star Wars" units such as Urai Fenn, and Tyber Zahn.  Why not make it Jabba the Hutt's faction and use all the bounty hunters from Empire Strikes Back for the Hero units?  They did include IG-88 and Bossk at least, but overall this faction doesn't feel like it came from Star Wars at all.The Empire is full of weird characters too.  If this game has moved away from Star Wars, then why the Hell am I playing it?  Not for the gameplay, that's for sure.Space Battles are kind of fun.  They look good, and feel like Star Wars, at least until the new, wacky Zann Consortium ships show up.  Ground Battles are terrible and have been terrible since the original game was released.  Ground battles are clunky, simplistic, poorly balanced, and just plain not fun.  And now that there is a bunch of Not From Star Wars units running around, I'm just playing a poorly designed, generic sci-fi rts on the ground.So lame.The Strategic Game/Empire Management?  Not very good.  Kind of boring--you play it because its Star Wars and it vaguely feels like you are commanding the Empire/Rebellion.  Again, the more the game moves away from actual Star Wars units and feel, the more Im asing myself why I am playing a clunky, poorly designed RTS game.  The answer is, I'm not.  I'm done with this crappy game and I do not recommend that you buy it.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												I remember this game rather fondly when I played it when it  first came out a few years back, Playing it now I only have one word, for it: Stale.It's kinda hard to pin down why, because on paper it all should work. It's a Star Wars game where they add Ground control style combat on land, Star trek Armada Style space combat (which was a pretty good RTS, not AMAZING but it worked) with Hyperspacing mechanics that allow you to reinforce just about anywhere.  Complete with a "Risk" style map ripped from Dawn of War. EDIT: I derped, Dark crusade came after this  Sounds great right?Well it just doesn't play as well as it sounds on paper. Again it's  hard to describe but it all just feels so bland. The units aren't terribly interesting (except some heroes), the textures are plain, yet muddy, and it all feels like they took a lot of concepts that were AMAZING in other RTS games (Ground Control's Dropzone mechanics, CNC Tanks, Company of Heroes' Squads, Dawn of War: Dark Crusade's Risk map, Yes I am aware some of these came after this, but they still did it better) but didn't properly understand WHY those mechanics worked the way they did in those games and thus it ended up watering it all down.Granted if you are a fan of the Extended Universe before Disney De-canonized it you'll get a kick out of the extra units and characters (Where else will you have Kyle Kataran throw down with Mara Jade?). but all in all, to me it feels very bland and watered down.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												The expansion pack to this game, Forces of Corruption has containd a game breaking bug since it was initially released; to this date it has not been fixed.  The issues is noticed during the main campaign of the FoC; where, if a player corrupts a planet that one of the main characters is suppose to do a campaign mission on, then there is a chance that the character will become stuck on that planet, invisible.  The player will have no way to interact with the character or start the mission.  How you will notice, is that the character will suddenly vanish off of the map after completing the corruption mission.  No matter where you look, it won't be visible.  If you click on it's icon in the upper corner, it will direct you to the planet where the character was suppose to do the mission.  The reason is, because that character is stuck on the planet; just invisible.  This breaks the game.  The only thing you can do is return to an older save and avoid using corruption when you last did it.The fact that such an aggrivating bug exists in a released product, is enough to earn it a poor rating.Edit: I deleted some comments due to fallacies.  Just because you never experience a problem with a product; doesn't mean no problems exist.  You can go to the Star Wars wikipage for FoC and see the campaign bug mentioned on the page.  Granted it says that it was patched; but, obviously it wasn't done so effectively if it still persists for players.  There is literally a recent steam community discussion you can look up, where someone is describing the exact issue and multiple other members are trying to help them trouble shoot the issue.  The final concensus was: you guessed it, restart the campaign.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Played this back when it first came out in 2010 or so. It crashed pretty frequently-- usually during cut scenes.It still crashes during cut scenes, which is basically all the time. And it's the type of crash that freezes the system, forcing a restart.----------------------Did some recommended updates and reinstalled the game. Runs pretty well now and it doesn't crash nearly as often (but it still does).The original is pretty fun. Really interesting game, scratches the "star wars galactic conquest" notion but there's some weird mechanics.Hero units are ridiculously overpowered. Remember when Chewbacca and Han Solo killed a swarm of stormtroopers and ATSTs? Me neither.During battles the defending base generates a free unit, and will regenerate the unit whenever it dies- giving the defender a suicide trooper to constantly use. You'll see this in the first battle-- xwings constantly flying to their deaths. Random troops constantly charging your ATST. The attacker brought 100 stormtroopers? Well, you're going to get a free unit every 10 seconds so send that SOB in. If the attacker doesn't rush you basically win. But then this gets ridiculous when you have a higher-end factory and you get a free tank squad constantly.And then the expansion breaks the game. Red Alert 2: Yuri's Revenge was a great game. Yuri was pretty imbalanced but still beatable. In this, the "whatever they are/pirates" basically can cast spells to literally "take over entire system"-- and you're constantly "uh... why'd I just lose that system?"And then they're on a different research tree. The Rebels and Empire research new/upgraded units and build those. The "pirates" research upgrades and then the units receive those benefits. Suddenly the 10 fighter swarms that die in seconds have shields and bombs and are decimating your forces. And the pirates are still dumping those level-1 units out for the same price.Stick with the original. Or find a game with mods.

												Well, Steam has FRAK'ed US in the a** again !!!!This , SW:EAW Gold,  is normally a great deal at $10 (Wallmart, Discount Books & Games).Now, it went on sale this weekend .........sounds great, right??? Wrong.First a couple of issues....if you already bought the game (on CD / retail box version) and wanted to play your friends that just got the game from steam's download.......you going to have huge problems playing them online, through steam.Frankly, it won't happen....you will have to figure out how to play though the game's internal multi-player Internet (which will want you to make yet another account , email and password)So, after 3 hours of frustration of the CD not wanting to update from version 1.01 to 1.5.....you desided "FRAK IT", and buy the game though steam.Well, be prepared to kiss $8 good-bye.......because after you paided for the game, and got it installed, you will get hit with steam's Error :: Failed to Contact Key Server.So...once again, a good running game that worked well on CD, has been turned to crap when downloaded threw steam.Thanks alot, Steam. --Way to Go.

number of helpful: 2 of 26 people (8%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												On Steam it says I've barely played this game, but I played a TON of it when it first came out and didn't have it on Steam. Anyways, it's an old game, and I HATE to say it, but it has not aged well. At all. In fact, if I ever play it again, it will be entirely for nostalgia's sake, unfortunately. The problem is the balance, especially in land battles. The way everything is set up just feels weird. It feels like vehicles can die too easily, the Empire infantry weirdly stack up into box formations that just doesn't really fit with the Star Wars atmosphere, and the rocket artillery on the Rebel's side is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥LY overpowered, to the point where they can almost take out your entire military force at the beginning of a match (yet when you use them, they don't feel nearly as powerful). It's just kind of a weird game, and yes, the space battles are cool, but they have also aged to the point where unfortunately, it's just not worth it anymore. The meta game  (galactic conquest or whatever it's called) is also weird. A lot of time there are strangely fast time limits to win the game, which annoys me because it gives little time to really develop a nice army and tech that can really do damage. And since it's all in real time, it sometimes devolves into a game of tag, where each side has their core planets, and then all the outlying planets are taken by one side, then taken by another, and so on and so forth, and this is due to the unit cap, which restricts you from truly building a large enough force to take over the empire. There's so many connections to all of the planets that it's not easy to actually form a stronghold, and while there is strategy in that, the game isn't quite good enough to compell you to want to develop the skills to master that strategy. I don't think I ever finished a single galactic conquest map. I ended up just reverting to multiplayer (which I can only assume is dead now).If you played the game before, and just want nostalgia to kick in, maybe pick it up on a sale, but if you've never played it before, I'd say move on to better RTS games.

												It has potential. I like the idea with the galactic conquest where you have to attack the planet from space, then attack by land. The whole Galactic Conquest is really all it has going for it though, since multiplayer is soon to be shut down, and land battles suck so much. Space battles are good though. However, because the land battles suck so much, it even ruins the Galactic Conquest. That is the entire reason I really dont like this game. The land battles just completely destroy the experience for me. I dont understand the whole, click a button, and units go into automatic cover and are completely invinsible. I also dont understand the whole thing with 1 infantry can kick a tanks♥♥♥♥♥ For a person who has never played an RTS before, I'd say go for it, you'll get used to the whole combat system better than I did. If you are and RTS fan, then no, this game, in my honest opinion, sucks because the land battles just really, really make the game awful. If your just gonna buy it for the space battles, than go for it, but in that case get it on May 4th, but it is not worth the $20 price tag it has now. content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												This game makes me mad and i regret thinking it would be like Star Craft or Age of Empires. It looks and feels a lot like those games but it lacks the ballance opposition, clarity of objectives and ease of interaction that those games did so well. This game has the longest most-annoying tutorial i have ever seen in a game and STILL teaches you prectically nothing about how your units might be different in some way... DO NOT BUY THIS GAME! By the time you finish the tutorial, you won't want to play it anymore.  Watch the idiotic AI stand there and get killed by the enemy while chase them all ofver the map when they run away! I like being able to micro manage my Army; i don't like being required to micro manage every move of every troop just to prevent them from doing the stupidest thing possible. I'm an expert RTS gamer, but this game is nothing but hot mess of confusion. How anyone can play it at all is beyond me.

number of helpful: 1 of 24 people (4%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												Unimaginative and poorly made.I bought this game thinking that "Oh, I've always wanted to play a true Star Wars RTS!" and was very excited when picking this up.  Sadly, I was met with poor gameplay mechanics, tiny maps, and unimaginitive features.  It feels like someone came up with this idea by saying: "Hey, let's make a Star Wars RTS!""That sounds like a great idea, what should we make it about?""I don't know, lets wing it!"I'm not going to harp on how none of this makes sense lore-wise, because the fun and value is in the gameplay.  That being said, the gameplay is slow, repetative, and bland.  I played it for an hour-or-so, got off, and never wanted to go back.People claiming that this game is the "Best Stragety in the Star Wars Franchise" are, in my opinion, proping this game up too much.  There aren't many strategy games for Star Wars, but this is like saying "Halo Wars is the best strategy of the Halo Franchise!"  Tl;dr if you are a fan of Star Wars or the RTS Genre, don't buy this game.

number of helpful: 9 of 51 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2013
												The first of the Star Wars titles to enter the grand strategy genre, Empire at War was highly anticipated but failed to meet expectations. Major flaws plague every aspect of the game. The developer made the poor decision to make the strategy map run in real-time rather than in a turn-based fashion, resulting in the need for constant pauses and frantic clicking; land battles are campy and boring; and space battles leave no room for tactics, as the bigger fleet nearly always wins by default. This game was created with an obvious degree of laziness, and the result is a frustrating experience. One can only assume that this arose from complacency on the part of the developer; perhaps it was believed that the Star Wars factor would compensate for the game's obvious shortcomings. If so, the developer was very incorrect. Don't buy this game.

Posted: June 14, 2014
												This is the only Star Wars game i put over KOTOR in how much i like itI first picked the gold pack up a few years ago before i had steam, the game has 3 campaigns, one for the empire, one for the rebels, and in the forces of corruption expansion you get the consortium's campaign.The game looks great, although it dosent actualy look too good compared to the screenshots or other modern strategy games it holds up very well. It has a very good variety of units, although the balance on the consortium may be a bit off on the op side, its hard to notice when storming them with AT-ATs. The galactic conquest mode however is where most of your time will be spent, as it allows you to conquer the entire galaxy as your chosen faction. There is also skirmish mode but compared to the other modes you will not spend all that much time in them.10/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Quite an interesting RTS format, with a galaxy wide strategy mode and both space and land battles that are very exciting!Land battles are a bit different to typical RTS games, in that there's no real base building. The units you get for a battle are all the units you brought with you for the invasion, no more no less. You start out with just a few on the board, but by capturing control points around the map you can bring down additional forces via dropship.A few minor nitpicks: The 'accelerate game time' button (which you will use a lot, as you wait for buildings or units to be built in the galaxy overlay) isn't really that fast, and battles can feel a little sluggish at times.Apart from that though, definitely worth a look. There are mods out there for those who prefer Clone Wars battles, too!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Simply put. The venerable "Mac Daddy" of (non story driven) Star Wars video games.Sure theres a story but, who does that when you can conquer the Galaxy with a fleet of Imperial Star Destroyers, or crush the Imperial war effort with squadron upon squadron of X-wing fighters and Y-wing bombers, or even indulge your inner Hutt and corrupt the galaxy with slavery and intimidation.Sure the graphics are dated and theres a limited amount of playability in the main story. But with a host of mods online ranging from simple ship re designs to full scale Clone Wars overhauls (complete with Episode 1-3 heroes and villains from tv shows and movies), The range of galactic conquest ideas goes on and on, What happens if the Imperials wiped out Dantoine and Hoths rebel bases, what if the Rebellion retook courscaunt? It's all in your hands... or steam library so go on.Rule the Galaxy!

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												Honesly one of my all time favorite RTS's. Its a blast and there really aren't any bugs that I'm aware of. There is one annoying thing though. When you're in Galactic Conquest, and it's paused, you are unable to move unit formations in a fleet until you unpause it. Just a minor annoyance, not even sure if it's a big or not.Honest score: 9/10 Very very fun, especially with mods. Just be weary about any AI's over easy in Galactic Conquest; They'll bombard you with attacks that hold like 30+ infantry or fighters or something mundane to defend against. Also, auto-resolve is horrible, don't trust it. You'll lose waaaaaaaaaay more than you would normally. The way auto-resolve works is dumb, it's a number game; Whoever has more units, will almost always win (the game counts unit points, so 3 or 4 fighters (in a large battle) is equal to a capital ship)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												This game is the best of all the series posted here on Steam. If your looking for a game to micro manage units, build complex bases and defence, and lots more this is the game for you. Think of it as CIV 5 , expect better in everyway. You get to move units in real time no "taking turns", if you attack a planet ( city ) you get to send in your infantry/tanks/etc giving them specific orders of where to go, and depending on that, how much damage you will do to their base. Even with a simple squad of infantry, they can sneak around and destroy a building before escaping, breaking down your enemies defences for the main armada.The only bad thing about this game is that the developers left the game alone. And in turn  leaving the multiplayer lacking in players and "issues" take some time to fix if they do.Overall: a great game that more developers should look up to and reach for this games level of complexity. The graphics are still pretty decent for being made around 2009 and later.. which i can't say for some of these newer games like "Rust".

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												This game is truly a treat to strategy gamers.I would call myself a strategy fanatic since mostly the only games I ever play are strategy, and I will easily recommend this as being one of my top five. After the Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds installments, it seemed pretty hard to be able to follow up another decent strategy without making it too modernised and missing out key elements that make true strategy games, especially a Star Wars one also. But I can truly say they pulled it off with this game. This game is a crystal to the RTS genre and provides players with the ability to be able to Strategically take over the Galaxy, as three different factions fight for power - you have to use all assets at your disposal to assert your faction above others. This power can be asserted by RTS space battles, in which huge fleets massacre eachother, or in RTS ground battles, where every unit has a weakness and strength, meaning that combat must be played strategically.I recommend this game to anyone looking in the RTS genre, as even for the 20+ hours i've played it, it is a gem to the RTS genre.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												  I bought this game on May the 4th (thanks Gaben) and I've been wanting it for a long time after wtaching some gameplay videos and it was really fun. You could do skirmish, campaign and multiplayer (which doesn't work unfortunately). skirmish is where you could chose a space or land battle, and chose any map, then you would face off some bots. Multiplayer (I imagine) is where you could chose a land or space battle and then after trying to find a match you would face-off an actual person. You would need lots of patience to play this game because if you play skirmish or multiplayer it would usually take a long time since you need to slowly level up to the highest level in order to attack. Campaign is just, well campaign. As the Empire, your goal (I'm guessing) is to conquer as much planets as possibe until the enemy (or Jedi) has been defeated. Same thing works with Jedi as well. Overall this is a very good game and I recomend it.

Star Wars never had any good strategy games (Galactic Battlegrounds was just a pallette swap of Age of Empires II) until this game came out. This game has great graphics and has incredible customization and mod potential. This game is more about macro-managment, it's always great to see fleets collide and trade fire above a contested planet. Think of this as a poor man's version of the Total War series - more approachable and action oriented with lots of lasers and explosions. Can't foget those.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												I first played Empire at War when I was 9 and I have been hooked ever since. Now I'm 15 and I am still loving it. Although I personally never get tired of Story Mode and Galactic Conquest Mode, I occasionally look up mods (this game has some of the best mods of all time, even if you don't have the DLC expansion pack) and I love those too. I usually compare this game to Halo Wars on Xbox 360. The gameplay is very similar to upgrading buildings and telling troops where to go on the battlefield, and the space combat is exactly the same. There is an out of battle part of the gameplay (unless playing Skirmish Mode) where you send fleets and troops to other planets to attack, reinforce, or retreat. You also train troops and build ships and space stations for when you actually fight in this part of the game. There are heroes in the game you can play as (Darth Vader, Boba Fett, Han Solo, Chewbacca, Luke Skywalker (Red Squadron in base game only, Jedi Knight in DLC only), Yoda, and more). This game was a gateway drug to strategy games for me and I was obviously attracted to it as a Star Wars fanboy, but this really did get me into strategy games. The only thing I might be worried about is the fanboy level in this game. If you are not a fanboy, this game is still worth trying, but you might get bored way too early.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												If you like Star Wars or science fiction in general, and have an interest in real time strategy, I recommend this one. In single player there is the option to pause even during battle, so you don't have to worry about controlling all of your units with keyboard inputs.The space battles are the highlight, I personally enjoy the ground battles as well though. I have had limited success with the multiplayer. In gameplay terms, the Empire is more about brute force, the Rebels are about smart tactics. So you can look at it and see the Empire as easy mode and the Rebels as hard mode, or being two different playstyles.Though if you enjoy messing stuff up, play Force of Corruption and take Darth Vader into a space battle. Super Star Destroyer > All.
