number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												I am mostly going to review the Forces of Corruption expansion and compare it to the base game. Although I will also say that this is one of the best Real-time strategy games I have played so far. The new things that were added to the campaign are the ability to sabotage Rebel or Empire bases in other planets as well as the ability to view their formations secretly. The expansion also gave the ability to travel to other systems undetected using bribery, which could prove extremely useful if you do not want to engage a considerable fleet and rather just simply bypass them. Although the Zann Consortium has only 4 buildings in which it can produce units which is a drawback for me as the enemy AI has fewer buildings to destroy in Skirmish or Galactic Conquest mode, it is rectified by the ability to corrupt planets in the Campaign or GC mode. Once you corrupt a planet, either Rebel or Empire, you have the ability to acheive a unit exclusive to it (such as a Tartan Patrol Cruiser or a Marauder-Class corvette) using the balck market and other benefits such as Bribery and Corrupt Militia. The best addition to the game is that they added a few more units in skirmish mode, in addition to more buildables in skirmish games. The new units and ships in-game means that you would have more options into bringing reinforcements as opposed to just simply generating all the units and sending them all in one skirmish game. Another great addition is that three-way battles are now playable on certain maps in both land and space battles as well as the AI in skirmish games improving considerably.  Even though the Zann Consortium has fewer ships and units than the Rebels and The Empire, they rectify it with the firepower they have such as the Aggressor-class Star Destroyer and the Destroyer Droid Mark II. Overall, this expansion had more postive aspects than negative ones and I enjoyed the additions this game had to offer. Dissapointing to note though is that they completely shut down the multiplayer servers back in 2014. At least the LAN option is still available.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 11
												A great strategy game for Star Wars fans. From blowing up Alderaan to destroying the Death Star, space battles is where Empire at War thrives the most. The space battles are as good as most sci-fi, strategy games today. The ground battles are enjoyable, but not as enjoyable as games like Age of Empires 1 and 2. The campaigns are alright and do expand on the EU and some missions are really enjoyable. The Galactic Conquest mode is probably the best gamemode for Empire at War because it allows you to build the Death Star as the Empire and yes you can blow up planets. You can also conquer planets from the movies, like Tatooine and Coruscant. The expansion pack even takes the game further, by adding a new faction and allowing the Empre and the Rebellion the ability t build new ships like Darth Vader's Super Star Destroyer (Galactic Conquest only). Also, the mods for Empire at War expand the galaxy even more. Empire at War is a great game for Star Wars and strategy games fans everywhere and I highly reccomend it to anyone reading this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7, 2012
												As a strategy game, Empire at War delivers a true Star Wars experience. If you're into AT-ATs stomping around battlefields, Darth Vader knocking over 20 soldiers with Force push, or space battles thick with dozens of fighters swarming in between gargantuan capital ships, Empire at War will deliver all that in a fun, compelling package. You can't really lose in any game in which you can blow up a planet with the Death Star, can you? Combined with a presentation that is as epic as the films that inspired the game and a slick, dual-layered strategy design, Empire at War is easily recommendable to any strategy fan, especially those who are fond of George Lucas' space classic.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												A good bundle and a good set of games, with one serious flaw....The Forces of Corruption mission to Saleucami is corrupted, this has been a known issue since 2006. There is a work around, you must choose to corrupt the planet via the option that DOES NOT require the hero Urai Fen. Using him will cause him to glitch out and he will be unusable for the rest of the game, which is a game breaking glitch. You will either have to start all over or load an earlier save.Other than this serious glitch, the game is very fun, both the original game and the expansion. The original game has no glitch that i have experienced.Because the game is so old, the multiplayer function DOES NOT work, it says so in the game details if you missed that part.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												This game rocks. I've always loved rts and I've always loved star wars and this game really does a great job of combining the two. The split between empire-building by controlling and upgrading facilities on different star systems and the real time strategy of both space and land skirmishes remind me a of the Total War franchise and I like it a lot.The real time missions though are what gets me. You can just jump right into them from the main menu without doing a campaign - a live action space or land battle at your fingertips. Did you ever have those little figurines off the millenium falcon or of some star destroyers or x-wings? I used to play with those things; flying them around and making up little battles and narratives to go with them. This game gives you what you always wanted that experience to be. Good sized fleets and armies to fight even though you'll still find yourself wanting more. There are a couple of maps that allow you to fight more than one AI but not too many. The game does allow for the play of custom maps which is really neat in concept, if a little bit of a hassle to get too for....uh. well lazy people like me when it comes to these things. Overall this game is great and I would definitely reccomend it. Disney, this game would make for a great sequel, especially with the great reception of the recent Total War games (once the bugs were fixed). I would love bigger maps!

												This game is basically a big toybox of Star Wars stuff. You can make your own dream scenarios in the map editor (which is somewhat confusing but I figured it out after awhile and it's simple for quick skirmish maps.) number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												It's a very interesting game, you have elements of a 4x4 game, a normal RTS game, and capture point RTS.Simple explantion of a game: Many planets, some have perks. You first sent your fleet over, than you attack it and take control. You have pre-made units that you deploy to the plant. Than you build on the planet whatever you want. I enjoyed the concept that you need more than one fleet to protect choke point planets and sometimes you need a ground presence, but generally if your fleet is destroyed and your planted is invaded it's not going to be much of a battle because you can only keep "X" amount of units actually on a planet. The game starts to go wrong half way through the game:1. Space battles. As the Empire you can not build normal tie fighters, they come from your crusiers. The Empire does feel stronger in space when you are the rebels, but when you play them they are capped at 20 compared to Rebels being caped at 25. Which would be fine, but you're two major big ships cost more points compared to the Rebels big ships. Overall the space battles are interesting but at the same time you're fleet doesn't seem to respond very well to what you want them to do. More so when you hit a ships special ability. 2. Ground battles When you play as the rebels your missle soilders are a key fuction, they deal a great deal of damage to vehicels. When you play as the Empire they seem to do even more against you. Which is fine in the long run, yet as the Empire you don't have any missle toting storm troopers. Vehicles are too easily defeated, they seem to die quicker than soilders. More so they don't seem to deal a lot of damage, even the big ATT shots at the rebels soilders and the damage isn't near what you would think it would be. Yet somehow you need them.The speeder bikes for the Empire are sort of pointless. They are suppose to drop a little bomb, but by the time you click on it your bike is blown apart, and your lone storm trooper is doomed. They are meant for exploring and doing quick bombing runs but it never works out. You don't need to scout...You know there are a ton of baddies (or goodies-depends how you feel about the rebels) in the location where you are sending them.The Rebels assult speeder is basically untouchable, nothing the rebels have can really damage it. It's not like they do a lot of damage, but they can bring down your ATT with the cable lines. Since none of their soilders or tech have something to bring a flying unit down you have to hope there is a pod where you can build a missle bay. Even than your range is very limited. The main isssue is the balance, there is not a lot of countering. Your standard battle is mostly about getting another capture point to bring in more units, and getting close enough to do a bombing run which destroys a building in one shot along with anything around it.  It's pretty much a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥contest latter in the game and you fighting till you can bomb again, 2-3 bombing and a capture point is how you win.  Strategy goes out the window. With that said it's a fun game and even when the game isn't on sale it's worth playing. This is one of the games where it's not a thumbs up or a thumbs down, it's just OKAY. Hardcore Star war fans will probably love it, but it just seems like they could have done a lot more with the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												Let me start by saying this game is not flawless by any means. It can be a bit simple, especially compared to other RTS games like Starcraft. However, the voice acting, character design, references to the explanded universe, and multitude of units make this game a ton of fun for a seasoned star wars veteran, and nothing beats getting into a space battle and bringing in the Executor, Vader's mammoth star destroyer, and ripping your enemies in two. Similiarly the ground battles are a ton of fun. My main complaint with this game is in its expansion, Forces of Corruption. It adds another faction to the mix, that in my opinion is incredibly unbalanced, particularly in Galaxy Conquest where their use of Defilers can constantly destroy building, requiring you to clear the corruption with either Thrawn, Vader or the Emporer. Overall a great game, witha few nagging problems.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												Personally, as a casual strategist, I think that this is a really great and fun game. Overall, most of the controls and mechanics are solid, and of course it doesn't look fabulous, but the graphics are not bad and, to me, the game looks fine. Besides, a little less graphical quality helps it run better on non-dedicated gaming machines. The AI in the game are not super hard, and you will find things about bad ground AI, but to me the AI in ground battles has been fine, and the space battle AI is still good. Really huge Star Wars fans would love this game, as well as many casual strategists.Rebel campaign, in my opinion, seems a little harder early on - you don't really have a ship equal to light Imperial cruisers, though you do have bombers.Besides, some of the space battles can get pretty awesome, with large fleets of Star Destroyers or Mon Calamari ships.For those who don't want to do a lengthy campaign, there is a solid skirmish mode.Overall, a solid game that looks alright and is pretty fun for most strategists.SIDE NOTE: One of my favorite, somewhat ridiculous battles that I had was as the empire in the campaign mode.(LOOKS AT INCOMING FLEET) 1 missile ship, okay.6 corellian corvettes: my Acclamators can handle them.21 squadrons of Z-(21?)s: That's alot.56 squadrons of X-wings: This is going to take a while.Proceeds to epic battle as hordes of X-wings pummel helpessly at the shields of my Cruisers as they laser the Corvettes into oblivion and then slowly mop up X-wings, since they are not good anti-fighter ships.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												I've played these games (EAW and FOC) since they came out and bought the gold pack on steam a while ago.The campaigns are fun and interesting if you're a fan of the original Star Wars trilogy. In EAW you may play as empire or rebels. While two different stories they both lead up to the construction of the death star.In FOC you are a third factor, the pirates of the Zann Consortium, and the time line is from some time before Return of the jedi and beyond.There are still some bugs in there, and if you want a competive RTS there are better options due to bad game balance. In particular this is a problem in the expansion where the Zann Consortium are ridiculously powerful. But if you are a Star Wars fan you will love this game and spend many hours in single player mode.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												This is a great addition to the Star Wars gaming universe. Although it is ancient, it's still a really good and entertaining game and boasts a great real time strategy campaign system. Playing as the Empire or the Rebels, one can see what it is like commanding the armies that participated in the Galactic Civil War. You have the fate of the galaxy resting in your hands. How will you win? By Rebel subterfuge? Or by blowing up Rebel planets with the infamous Death Star I.Empire at War Forces of Corruption was alright. I liked some of the additions but the campaign was ultimately a little dull and rushed. If one plays as the Zann Consortium, the game is really easy. If not, you will get screwed by them. The new planets were cool. I also liked some of the Empire troops like Dark Troopers and Tie Interceptors.Ultimately, this game is worth the money. Getting the RaW (Republic at War) mod is also pretty cool as it takes the scope to new levels but that is independent of Steam. Good buy. Been playing this game for almost ten years since it came out and it hasn't gotten old.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												The game is fun, especially if you play as Tyber Zann, because it introduces a new concept to Star Wars games: CRIME. The Zann Consortium is infinitely more interesting than most Star Wars factions, at least to me.Simply put, the only issue with the game is repetition. The game itself really only offers 2 single player modes: campaign and conquest. The former has a short storyline that you can beat in a couple of hours (if you take your time) and conquest is just capturing planets, over and over again. This is essentially the same for multiplayer.The bottom line: If this game is on sale for a few bucks, I'd say it's worth it but I wouldn't suggest spending 20 bucks on it. It simply doesn't provide enough replay value, unless you reinstall it once a year or so.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												The game was first released in 2006, and the graphics are very much of that time.  But the gameplay is still a classic in terms of strategy base-building games.  There is a narrative to the game but that is mainly to flesh out a plot for you for to build an army and to attack and invade planets.  Ground warfare consists of taking landing zones to gain not only a foothold on the planet, however, it is also to increase the size of your army due to the cap level placed, and as your tech upgrades furthers your army's capabilities, so does it make your space fleet stronger, and space is the gem of where this game is at.  Corruption brings to bear all that is shown in Star Wars VI: The Return of the Jedi, employing everything from X Wing and Tie fights, to superstar destroyers and death stars.  Quite simply, this game is brilliant, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking to play a simple build and conquer game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												The concept of this game is pretty fantasitc. Other RTS's, such as: Warcraft III and Starcraft and Command and Conqore with Red Alert as well, you build your base and then your army, and then you attack/defend. This game you build your base  on other planets, then your army, then you take your army and attack the enemy base which is on another planet. The ideal behind this is the person playing defense has the advantage. They have factories that will constantly put out troops, while you are limited to the troops that you brought. You attack their space station and their defenses, while they continually get backup. So you have to work quick to bring them down. Making this a unique and interesting approach to the classic RTSHowever this game is not without its quirks. It is starting to show age and some of the units are not fully balanced. But since the multiplayer really never kicked off, they didnt keep messing with it. Yet this doesnt take away from the fact that it is a fun game to play, especially when you are with your buddies/roomies and just have a lan party for an hour or so, or just play single player. The skirmish battles with a hard AI is quite the challenge.So dispite its setbacks, this game still pleases, even after all these years.8/10

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												One of the best RTS games ever made and probably amongst the best Star Wars games, too.In Empire at War, you'll have the option to command three factions (assuming you have the Gold Edition): The Galactic Empire, the Rebel Alliance and the Zann Consortium. Each faction has dozens of unique unities with unique habilities assinged to them. There are many modes of play available, including a campaing for each of the factions, the Galactic Conquest mode, which will have you using the best of your habilites to complete specific objectives in the galactic map and the well known skirmish mode. There is also, of course, multiplayer.Graphics are great, sound effects are flawless, soundtrack lends from most of the original tracks from the trilogy of movies, so you can bet your♥♥♥♥♥there is going to be some great music playing while you blast your way through the galaxy with the Death Star at your side. All the characters you expect to see will be there plus a few more. Played this game pretty much in every possible way before I got bored back when it came out.  Replayed it on Steam all these years later and it haven't aged a day, still had fun with it. If you're a fan of the genre, there is not much to think about. There might be a few flaws here and there, like the camera zoom being locked pretty closed and the actual amount of units permitted per battle being rather low, but this game is unbelievably good. Get it.Gameplay - 7/10Soundtrack - 10/10Graphics - 7/10Content - 8/10Challenge Level - 8/10Replayability - 8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												A suprisingly good starwars game despite the glut of terrible ones produced by the late Lucas Arts.  It has a very strange system that I have not seen in a game that I remember.  You have the campaign map, but it is not static.  You generate money pretty quick and the enemy can attack you at anytime.  The land and space battles are similar to say what total war is on a much smaller and different scale, but there is no pause after on the campaign.  The difference in difficulty between the rebel campaign and the imperial campaign is huge.  As the empire you should have no problem steam rolling the alliance.  Imperial ships are heavily armored, carry free tie fighters, and have more fire power than most rebel ships.  Your land units will also destroy people.  ATATs can produce squads of free storm troopers meaning you have the best anti veicle and decent anti infantry that cost nothing.  The alliance campaign on the other hand can be frusturating.  Get read to have the auto resolve tell you that your fleet can own 10 victory star destroyers only to play it out and be destroyed.  Because you rely on figters so much, and the Y wing is your only chance against imperial capital ships, its devastating when a Tantun cruiser kills almost all of them in 10 seconds.  Managing ships is hard.  With the empire you just send in your gugernauts and they kill everything.  With the alliance untill you get the assault frigate expect to see your capital ships blown out of orbit.  The nebulon B frigate (medical frigate) is really only good at giving Luke a robot arm and being blown to peices.  Luckily even if you cant hold space, you can hold planet surfaces if you invest in defenses.  The battles can be tense though.  But just as shields are hard for you, they are for the enemy.  Rebel infantry are really good, just watch out for the over powered tie maulers who can just run your entire army over at 60mph.  Still the best starwars RTS I can think of, and there are lots of mods.  I think there is even a 40k mod.

												I've been wanting to check out this game for a while, and now that I've played it, I'm happy I did.From my initial experience, the tutorials only give you the basics of how to play (even the advanced tutorials). This in no way was a negative thing, for those that might be deterred by games that are difficult initially. The real learning experience and enjoyment comes from learning your own way around (which really shouldn't take over a few hours) and then seeing your strategies come to life as you obliterate those rebel scum!If you're a lover of RTS games or even just strategy, I implore you to play this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												This game rocks. I've always loved rts and I've always loved star wars and this game really does a great job of combining the two. The split between empire-building by controlling and upgrading facilities on different star systems and the real time strategy of both space and land skirmishes remind me a of the Total War franchise and I like it a lot.The real time missions though are what gets me. You can just jump right into them from the main menu without doing a campaign - a live action space or land battle at your fingertips. Did you ever have those little figurines off the millenium falcon or of some star destroyers or x-wings? I used to play with those things; flying them around and making up little battles and narratives to go with them. This game gives you what you always wanted that experience to be. Good sized fleets and armies to fight even though you'll still find yourself wanting more. There are a couple of maps that allow you to fight more than one AI but not too many. The game does allow for the play of custom maps which is really neat in concept, if a little bit of a hassle to get too for....uh. well lazy people like me when it comes to these things. Overall this game is great and I would definitely reccomend it. Disney, this game would make for a great sequel, especially with the great reception of the recent Total War games (once the bugs were fixed). I would love bigger maps!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												The concept of this game is pretty fantasitc. Other RTS's, such as: Warcraft III and Starcraft and Command and Conqore with Red Alert as well, you build your base and then your army, and then you attack/defend. This game you build your base  on other planets, then your army, then you take your army and attack the enemy base which is on another planet. The ideal behind this is the person playing defense has the advantage. They have factories that will constantly put out troops, while you are limited to the troops that you brought. You attack their space station and their defenses, while they continually get backup. So you have to work quick to bring them down. Making this a unique and interesting approach to the classic RTSHowever this game is not without its quirks. It is starting to show age and some of the units are not fully balanced. But since the multiplayer really never kicked off, they didnt keep messing with it. Yet this doesnt take away from the fact that it is a fun game to play, especially when you are with your buddies/roomies and just have a lan party for an hour or so, or just play single player. The skirmish battles with a hard AI is quite the challenge.So dispite its setbacks, this game still pleases, even after all these years.8/10

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												If you like Star Wars or science fiction in general, and have an interest in real time strategy, I recommend this one. In single player there is the option to pause even during battle, so you don't have to worry about controlling all of your units with keyboard inputs.The space battles are the highlight, I personally enjoy the ground battles as well though. I have had limited success with the multiplayer. In gameplay terms, the Empire is more about brute force, the Rebels are about smart tactics. So you can look at it and see the Empire as easy mode and the Rebels as hard mode, or being two different playstyles.Though if you enjoy messing stuff up, play Force of Corruption and take Darth Vader into a space battle. Super Star Destroyer > All.

												Bought this off steam 2 days ago and already logged 30 hours (after logging about 500 hours from owning disk, but I misplaced that). Fantastic game, non-debatable. Space battles are amazing and sometimes require tactics, great feature, but land battles are mediocre, and playing "cat and mouse" with that last dammed platoon of Plex soilders isn't the best thing to look for.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Don't let my time online discourage you, I've played this game to death offline.Empire at War is a stunning Real Time Strategy revolving around the 'Rise of the Empire era' Star Wars universe. The main game allows you to take the sides of both the Galactic Empire and the Rebel Alliance across varied planets and participate in epic space battles above said planets. Famous environments such as Hoth, Endor and Coruscant return as well as lesser known planets from spin offs and extended universe canon.Ultimately you control either faction with the goal of controlling every location in the galaxy. Along the way you will participate in skirmishes with land forces and space fleets and combat your enemies in engaging and clever ways. Land battles see you build bases and call in ground troops from your fleet in space to wipe out the enemy presence while space battles see you attacking or defending a space station with a wide range of units such as fighters, frigates and capital ships.The expansion pack, Forces of Corruption, adds a third faction and a wide array of new locations, units, and ways to play.  You can now play as the Zahn Consortium, a group of intergalactic space pirates who want their own share of the galaxy. The new setting takes place during the galactic war and sees you entering the fight between the Rebels and the Empire.This is an amazing RTS that really captures the feeling of being a part of the Star Wars universe. If there's only one Star Wars game you should play, this is it.

												As your Star Destroyer enters the system only one task remains: Destroy the Rebel Fleet. This game may be old but it still is better than most RTS games out there. Its fun and entertaining. Easy to get into and has a lot of replay value. Buy this game its worth it.
